story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Exclusive:&nbspMP says firm is stretching public goodwill in ‘unacceptable’ wayBoots could be risking investigation under minimum wage legislation after recruiting hundreds of volunteers to carry out coronavirus testing for the government, employment lawyers have warned.And the Trades Union Congress&nbspsaid that ads for the unpaid posts, which state that applicants must be ready to work at least 32 hours a week testing NHS staff who fear they may have Covid-19, appeared to be “out of kilter” with the spirit of volunteering for the national effort to beat the disease.MP Stewart McDonald wrote to Boots managing director Sebastian James branding the arrangement –&nbsprevealed on Wednesday by The Independent&nbsp– as “unacceptable”. Mr McDonald said it was “stretching the volunteering goodwill that the public has so admirably displayed to the point of being negligible”.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe SNP MP for Glasgow South demanded to know whether the company was receiving government payment for the tests or offering its services for free.Other firms advertising for operatives to work at drive-through Hospital, during a minutes silencePolice officers observe a minutes silence at Guy's HospitalIt is understood that many of the volunteers recruited by Boots are furloughed workers who do not want&nbspto take on paid employment for fear of risking their status, under which the state pays 80 per cent of their wages while they cannot do their usual jobs. Boots says it is not making any profit out of the scheme.But legal expert Lucy McLynn, head of employment at law firm Bates Wells, said that treating the testers as volunteers “feels pretty abusive” and may fall foul of minimum wage legislation, which is policed by HM Revenue and Customs.The law exempts charities and fundraising bodies from the requirement to pay the £8.72-an-hour national living wage to people volunteering to help them, but does not allow companies to treat people as volunteers if they are taking the role of a worker, she explained.“I think Boots are in rather dangerous territory with this, because the time commitment suggests these people are more like workers,” Ms McLynn told The Independent.“HMRC has powers to enforce the Minimum Wage Act and this looks set to be a high-profile arrangement, so they may feel they want to look at it.”The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive updates on politics every morning by emailAll teachers and pupils to be tested if they develop virus symptomsCovid test results from commercial labs not shared with local NHSArmy of volunteers being recruited to carry out coronavirus testsMatt Hancock urged to improve ‘trustworthiness’ of coronavirus figureA volunteer agreement letter to be signed by those taking part in the scheme states that it is not creating an employment relationship. The company says will be flexible about the times to be worked, but adds that it is&nbsp”vitally important” that participants attend testing sites at the hours agreed. Volunteers are asked to give as much notice as possible if they&nbspwant to stop,&nbspso that rotas can be rearranged.Employment law barrister Nicola Braganza, of Garden Court Chambers, said the recruitment ads raised “a number of serious concerns”. Volunteer workers would miss out not only on pay but also on holiday entitlements and discrimination protections, she said.“They appear to be relying on the goodwill of people to agree to work without pay or the benefit of any employment rights protection,” said Ms Braganza. “Other companies are paying staff to do the same work.“Describing a person as a volunteer will not necessarily mean that they are in fact and in law a volunteer. The advert refers to a mandatory requirement to carry out specified contracted hours.“Volunteers are asked to work long hours in physically and mentally demanding roles and presumably expected to comply with whatever instructions they are given.&nbspAll of this tends to undermine that the relationship is a genuine volunteer – one with no mutuality of obligation.”TUC employment rights officer Tim Sharp told The Independent that the company’s approach appeared to be at odds with the spirit seen when 700,000 people signed up to volunteer to help the NHS, at a time when many Boots employees were being paid by the state under the furlough scheme.“It seems to me to be out of kilter with the spirit of the volunteering initiative, which was all about bringing in people who wanted to help out the health service,” he said. “Here we have a large business trying to recruit people to do what seem to be skilled and important roles which should be paid accordingly.”In his letter to Mr James, Mr McDonald said he was “curious as to why neither Boots nor the UK government are offering pay and employment benefits to testers”.“I am keen to know whether Boots has been contracted and receiving government funding for recruiting volunteers or if Boots is just offering its services to the government for free,” he said.“Advertising these high-risk but crucial roles as volunteering would be to take advantage of the public’s goodwill. Whilst similar opportunities are offered as paid roles, Boots should be treating their applicants the same –&nbspfairly and properly as the key workers that they are.”A Boots spokesperson said: “Boots stepped forward to support Covid-19 testing for frontline workers at the request of the government and we are proud to play our part in helping the NHS and other frontline workers return to work.“During this phase of the crisis, this has not been in any way a commercial activity, and Boots has not sought to make any profit, only to support the NHS and the country as we have done for over 170 years.“Our role in the UK testing programme, run by the Department of Health and Social Care, is to provide and train testers for some of the UK drive-through testing sites. Many Boots employees have come forward to take part and train as testers.“We have also agreed to help with the recruitment of additional volunteers where required. We have been really pleased with the response to our request, with hundreds of people stepping forward to volunteer to do this vital work.”A spokesperson for HMRC declined to comment on the inidual case, but said that enforcement officers were empowered to investigate minimum wage cases “if we have cause for concern either if we receive intelligence or our own records show that there is an apparent discrepancy which needs looking into”.HMRC guidance for officers states that people described as volunteers may in fact be classed as workers entitled to the minimum wage if they are unable to withdraw their services at any time, if they are subject to requirements, obligations or standards from the organisation involved or if they are receiving training or any payment beyond necessary expenses.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - A five-year-old boy, a seven-year-old boy and an 18-year-old girl, Mr Cuomo said. These cases are all across the state, predominantly where the population is.Seven charts that show the true scale of the UK coronavirus outbreakThe Americans who think that coronavirus is a hoaxHow to feel less anxious about the coronavirusQuarantine: What do new UK travel guidelines mean for my holidays?He added that 14 other states and five European countries were also looking into the rare syndrome to see if there was a link to those symptoms and the novel virus.About 60 per cent of the 102 cases in New York tested positive for the coronavirus. Of those cases,&nbsp70 per cent&nbspwere admitted&nbspinto the ICU and 19 per cent resulted in intubation.The potential link between the coronavirus and these inflammatory syndromes has caused concern among officials because children are presenting symptoms far different from the typical Covid-19 patient. But symptoms related to the rare inflammatory disease instead show&nbspswelling and redness in the body's blood vessels.An estimated&nbsp3,000 children are diagnosed with Kawasaki disease in the US each&nbspyear.“These are children who come in who don’t present the symptoms that we normally are familiar with with Covid. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Secretary of state’s visit lasted just six hours and came a day before Israel’s&nbspunity government is due to be sworn in&nbspMike Pompeo&nbspwaived strict coronavirus travel restrictions to fly to&nbspIsrael&nbspon Wednesday for a lightning visit, meeting with Benjamin Netanyahu&nbspand his power-sharing partner Benny Gantz to discuss a&nbspMiddle East&nbsppeace deal&nbspand Israeli plans to annex parts of the occupied West Bank.The&nbspsix-hour&nbspvisit came just a day before&nbspMr Netanyahu’s unity government with Mr Gantz,&nbspa former army chief, was due to be sworn in, and as violence flared in the Palestinian territory.Hours before the US secretary of state touched down in Tel Aviv, an Israeli soldier shot and killed a&nbsp15-year-old Palestinian during a confrontation near the city of Hebron.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesA manhunt was also underway after an Israeli soldier was killed on Wednesday&nbspduring an army raid in the north.With permission to ignore Israel’s mandatory two-week quarantine for foreign visitors, Mr Pompeo donned a red, white and blue face mask and headed straight to meetings in Jerusalem.Israel’s top court paves way for Netanyahu’s unity deal with GatnzThere he expressed his condolences for the soldier’s death, saying “Israel has the right to defend itself”.He discussed about issues with Iran as well as advancing Donald Trump’s peace plan, which in January triggered widespread condemnation from the Palestinians, Arab states and members of the international community, including the UK, for crushing hopes of a viable Palestinian state.Labelled as the most pro-Israeli vision for the Middle East, the document hands the contested city of Jerusalem to Israel as its capital in addition to 30 per cent of the West Bank.The occupied territory is home to over 3&nbspmillion Palestinians, as well as some 750,000 Israelis who live in settlements deemed illegal under international law.“There remains work yet to do, and we need to make progress on that.&nbspI’m looking forward to it,” Mr Pompeo said of moves to implement the peace plan.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailAhead of the visit, Mr Pompeo told&nbspIsrael Hayom that it was ultimately “Israel’s decision” to push ahead with annexation.On Wednesday, Mr Pompeo also spoke about Iran during his trip, claiming the regime was using its resources to “foment terror across the world”, even while struggling with the coronavirus pandemic.Israeli inventors make $500 ventilators as hospitals scramble for moreFrom Israel to the US, coronavirus supplies are going awryWhy Netanyahu is the real winner in Israel’s power-sharing dealNetanyahu self-isolating after aide tests positive for Covid-19Israel intelligence services to track phones of Coronavirus patientsWith Mr Trump facing election in November, Mr Netanyahu and his nationalist support base are keen to move ahead quickly with unilaterally taking over parts of the West Bank like the strategic Jordan Valley.The premier hopes to maximise the Trump administration’s pro-annexation stance, particularly as presumptive Democratic nominee, Joe Biden, has repeatedly said he opposes annexation plans.But Israel is facing mounting pressure to ditch the plans&nbspfrom outside the States.On Monday, the UK’s junior Foreign Office minister James Cleverly spoke out against the imminent annexation of parts of the West Bank, telling the British parliament&nbspit would make a two-state solution with the Palestinians more difficult to achieve.The EU is also reportedly mulling sanctions against Israel should it press ahead with annexation. There is no certainty that support for annexation is an electoral boost for the administration,” he added.He noted that a six-hour visit to Israel amid intense coronavirus restrictions and fears it could pose a risk to health was “crazy”.Addressing the secretary of state on Wednesday, Mr Netanyahu hinted that the formation of his new government with Mr Gantz would allow Israel to push ahead with annexation.Under the terms of the new unity government deal, the government can begin pushing forward legislation allowing annexation from the 1 July.Mr Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister, has battled to hold on to power after being indicted&nbspon corruption charges&nbsphe vehemently denies.Following three inconclusive elections in less than a year and weeks of fierce negotiations, he managed to cement a power-sharing rotation deal with Mr Gantz.Under the arrangement, Mr Netanyahu remains prime minister for 18 months, before the Mr Gantz takes over for the second half of the term.Mr Gantz, less hawkish than Mr Netanyahu, previously insisted that annexation not be unilateral but instead implemented “in coordination with the international community”.Israel captured the West Bank, east Jerusalem and Gaza Strip in the 1967 Middle East war. title: boris convice brits overcome coronavirus
story: BORIS JOHNSON needs to do some straight talking tonight.The PM has overcome Covid-. He now needs to convince frightened Britons that we can safely overcome the pandemic’s brutal economic impact.Boris himself admits that we are entering a new danger zone. But there is little time left to get Britain back on track before the economy slides into meltdown.He needs to spell out when and how we can resume our everyday lives — without it damaging our health. The scale of the PM’s challenge is revealed in our poll today.Seven weeks after people were asked to accept unprecedented restrictions on their lives, a staggering  per cent are opposed to any easing at this time. The public’s response to this challenge has been magnicent, but there is an urgent need to get Britain working again.The cost of the furlough scheme alone is already an eye-watering £billion and is spiralling by an unsustainable £.billion a day.Our poll shows most people are far more afraid of a second wave of coronavirus than the risk of losing their jobs. Only one in  believe the measures should end, and just four per cent favour an immediateto work.Boris must use his address to the nation tonight to instil confidence that “unlockdown” will be measured and safe.But he must not underplay the uncomfortable truth: It is time people grit their teeth and get the economy going again.Give it to us straight, PM.CHANCELLOR Rishi Sunak’s furlough scheme has thrown millions of British workers a generous leline during the crisis.But it is outrageous when the mega-rich take advantage of it at the expense of the taxpayer.The latest are the Hinduja brothers, worth £billion, who are using the Government’s hand-outs to pay employees at one of their firms.As Britain’s richest family, why can’t they pay staff out of their own deep pockets CHINA has an enormous stake in Britain, with investments worth over £billion.As one of the world’s most powerful economies, it will also be crucial to post-Brexit trade.But this secretive and authoritarian country must not be let off the hook over its role in the coronavirus outbreak.Britain has been too slow to join other nations in pressing for a full inquiry. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: trevor kavanagh lockdown terrible mistake
story: “I had dficulty not wanting Boris Johnson to die. I wanted him to die,” she told Channel  cheerleaders.The Harry Potter star is the authentic voice of Corbynistas who loathe this Prime Minister with a visceral hatred.If they can’t dance on his grave, the Dementors will do everything possible to kill his political career.Covid- has morphed from a battle for the nation’s health into a lethal struggle to stop Boris leading Britain successfully out of lockdown.An early victory came last night, as the PM unveiled his new slow-motion escape motto.Some ministers hoped for: “Back to work. Go to school. Save the economy.”Instead we heard a feeble “Stay alert. Control the virus. Save lives.”This is a Prime Minister paralysed by indecision, kicking himself for unforced errors, terried of being blamed for every new death.Downing Street is now hostage to the health-and-safety mafia, whipped into line by opportunist public sector unions who have, to coin a phrase, taken back control.Teaching unions, already on guaranteed public sector pay, even want to restrict some online lessons for education-hungry kids.Transport unions are making Tube, rail and bus travel impossible with draconian social distancing.Health unions blame ministers for blunders made by NHS and Public Health England managers.We are in thrall to a shroud-waving public sector “blob” warning of mass fatalitiesthe Government makes one  step.We must heed the experts who swallowed “Bonking Professor” Neil Ferguson’s crackpot forecasts of half a million dead without lockdown.They are the same experts whose advice on testing, PPE and care homes led to one of the world’s biggest death tolls.The nation’s long-term physical, mental and economic health is being held to ransom by a bug which has virtually no impact on children, young adults and most people under .That same low-risk generation faces a potentially catastrophic price for a disease which should leave them and their parents free toalmost immediately to normal le.Coronavirus is an old person’s disease. Out of ten million under-s in Britain, just two have sadly died from Covid-.For under-s, the risk is a “trivial” one or two per million, says respected statistician Sir David Spiegelhalter. Little more than the chance of dying by accident.For over-s, he says the risk is “ten thousand times” as high.This is no consolation for elderly victims, but it does suggest a speedy route back to a new normal with productive under-s kick-starting the economy.Getting people back to work will be hard. The work ethic propelling us out of bed each morning has been sapped by warm spring sunshine, online food and wine and a Treasury- funded cost of living subsidy.People are enjoying paid-for-time with their families. they are also scared witless by sermons about death and disaster and Downing Street’s daily mortality rate briefings.One day there will be a public inquiry. Everyone is covering their tracks.With hindsight, global lockdown is likely to be judged a terrible mistake, forced on a panic-stricken world by China’s authoritarian example.Sweden alone rejected lockdown, keeping schools open, and the economy ticking over, yet its death toll is lower per head than Britain, France, Spain and Italy.Former Swedish medical chief, Professor Johan Giesecke, believes we overreacted to a disease which is just twice as severe as winter flu and cannot be avoided anyway.“I don’t think you can stop it,” he says, “it’s like a tsunami sweeping across Europe.“We should do what we can to slow it so the health service can cope, but let it pass.”But he won’t say this in public.He will have seen the bizarre charges of betrayal and “fat shaming” against singer Adele for daring to lose seven stone.Yet Liverpool University researchers say obesity increases the risk of death from coronavirus by  per cent.Boris should say loud and clear that fat can be fatal. Losing weight prolongs le.Our health service, by the way, has coped brilliantly.Prof Giesecke says there are three golden rules: “Wash your hands, keep social distance, trust the people.”After Brexit, Boris should know more than most he can trust the people.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rhetoric wont save economy
story: WE urge all Brits to keep in mind two truths over the coming weeks.One: Coronavirus is a deadly and highly contagious disease, and although we are over the first peak of infection, it still poses a huge threat to this nation.Two: The Government can’t bail out Britain indefinitely. Andwe are to avoid bankruptcies, whopping tax rises and mass unemployment, the country mustto work ASAP.The conditional plan Boris Johnson laid out last night for eventually reopening society delicately balances these two facts. And The Sun cautiously welcomes it.Now, the Prime Minister must get the leaders of Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales  per cent on side.We know that’s easier said than done: Nicola Sturgeon thrives on creating trouble.But she must be told that the public won’t forgive politiciansthey fail to work together while the nation is under siege.And we stand the best chance of defeating this devilish enemywe act as a United Kingdom.The PM must also urgently clear up some questions around the new rules.Does “limit contact with other people” mean we can have contact with others as long as we keep it limited  If so, what’s the limit  And which other people What exactly does “drive to other destinations mean ” Are we now allowed on cross-country jaunts to the coast  Or just five miles down the road And how on earth are parents working in industries such as manufacturing and construction supposed to go back to work while their kids are stuck at home We accept that we’re being asked to use some level of common sense. But clarity is a crucial weapon in this particular war. And woolly guidance which is wide open to abuse really could cost lives.Last night, the Prime Minister proved once again that he’s an excellent speaker.But our economy is slowly suffocating. And rhetoric won’t save it.THE prospect of the Queen withdrawing from public le for the foreseeable future will come as a real blow to Brits.Our fabulous monarch has a knack for perfectly capturing the mood of the nation — and she is the constant we all need in this unpredictable new world.That said, it comes as a relief to us that she and her advisers are taking social distancing seriously.Her Majesty is  years old, and the most important thing is that she stays safe and well.One day, she’ll meet us again.And in the meantime, her wise and wonderful TV addresses will serve as a great comfort to us all. title: nail beauty shops reopen uk
story: PRIME Minister Boris Johnson outlined his plan to get the country back open in his address to the nation on Sunday, May , .One of the sectors that has been affected the most has been the hair and beauty industries, with many wondering, when they will be allowed to open again.Guidelines given by Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab on Monday, May , said that the hospitality sector - including hairdressers - would notto work before July .This would include beauty salons, which involve people being in close contact with one another.Beauty salons across the country have been closed since lockdown began on March .Mr Raab said that close proximity in the hospitality sector is something where we dont think were ready yet, given where we are with the virus.There has been more clarity on beauty parlours being reopened in Ireland, which has given July  as an official date for the beauty industry to open its doors again.Irish Prime Minister Taoiseach Leo Varadkar announced the roadmap for unlocking restrictions on Friday, May , .Nail salons were among the first to close when the nationwide lockdown was imposed on March , .As nail salons are also classed as hospitality, they too are expected to open at the beginning of July.The National Hair and Beauty Federationreleased a statement saying it backed Mr Raabs plans.It said: Dominic Raab has said that hospitality and ‘personal care services’ such as hair and beauty salons and barbershops in England will not be able to reopen until th July at the earliest.It is our view that this is the right course of action, as the safety of the people in our industry is paramount.The NHBF added that there were still concerns within the industry and a meeting with the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy would provide more clarity.Despite being closed since the lockdown, more than £MILLION worth of gt vouchers were sold during the month of April.These vouchers were purchased online, directly on salons’ websites or via social media s.If youre one of these people, sit tight, and your vouchers will be able to be redeemed for use once the beauty industry is back open for business.The government has pledged support to self-employed people in the United Kingdom as well as full-time workers.HMRC is contacting taxpayers eligible for the Self-Employment Income Support Scheme , with the claims service opening on Wednesday, May .The Sun has documented a guide on what support self-employed people can do to get financial help during the pandemic, which youabout here.If you are a beauty worker or nail technician who is employed then you employer can pay you through the Governments furlough scheme.You can read our guide on what the emergency measures mean for you.Others who see themselves as creative can conjure up new ways to supply the demand to their customers while at home, one nail technician did just that by doing, through the letterbox manicures,youre looking for some inspiration.If you are in you probably already sitting in your cupboards.Our DIY guide here gives great advice on dealing with such things as dealing with your bikini line, dying hair and tidying up your brows.Plus we show you title: first steps out of nightmare
story: FINALLY some clarity after a day of chaos triggered by Boris Johnson’s Sunday night address. The Government cannot afford to repeat such a shambles.“Stay home, save lives” was a simple and effective message. The next steps are far more nuanced.They did not need another vague Churchillian rallying call. That merely sowed confusion, even among the PM’s deputy Dominic Raab and the staunchest Tories, and exposed Boris to a tsunami of snark on TV and social media.It needed instead the level of detail we eventually saw in the Government’s guidance released yesterday afternoon — and then in Boris’s Commons QA.Supporters claimed the PM’s new “stay alert” message was merely common sense any fool could grasp. That misses the point. We are being asked to live in highly unusual and restrictive ways. One person’s common sense is another’s idea of dangerous risk.Our circumstances are all dferent and specics are important — especially when police are to hand out increased fines for transgressions.But while the Government’s recent messaging has been poor, we at least now have our first welcome, albeit ­tentative, steps out of this nightmare:Outside exercise without limit, including the freedom to drive for a day out. The first chance in weeks to see a friend. All assuming social distancing.More solid guidance on masks. Precious little relief on schools, but the glimmer of some sport. Some, many Sun readers included, are being told toto work, though they may justiably fear it is unsafe.Their jobs also make them some of those most likely to die from Covid-.Their firms, factories and sites must bust a gut to ensure their safety, take every precaution and heed reasonable concerns. The grim reality, though, is that our economy must get moving again.It is typical of the infantile Left to complain that profits are being put before people. The Government is not a bottomless well of money. That’s why Rishi Sunak is limbering up to cut the sums paid to furloughed staff. He has to.Only a healthy economy and the taxes it generates can keep public services afloat, the NHS especially.Bankrupt Britain with an endless lockdown and you wreck those too. And far more lives are then lost.DONALD Trump is now harbouring an international fugitive.His case for refusing Britain’s request to extradite Harry Dunn’s alleged killer Anne Sacoolas is blown apart.The Interpol Red Notice, ordering her arrest outside the US, shows the “diplomatic immunity” under which she left the UK after the death crash was bogus.Even the US public want her to face the music. They recognise injustice when they see it.Trump must put Sacoolas on a plane.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lose weight betrayal jane moore
story: A PRE-PANDEMIC survey warned that million British adults are now classed as obese – at a cost to the NHS of around £billion a year.Given that a UK report suggests two thirds of those who have fallen seriously ill with Covid- were either obese or seriously overweight, one wonders how many of those million are using these weeks of lockdown to make some le-saving changes that will not only benefit them but our over-stretched hospitals.After all, fast food restaurants have been closed and we all had much more time on our hands, so what better opportunity to rid ourselves of poor eating habits and get fit Better still, the likes of Joe Wicks and Mr Motivator are giving free, online fitness classes. All you need is a TV and the inclination.But while many will have used this virtual house arrest to shake off some unhealthy old habits , the reaction to Adele’s weight loss suggests that, for some, her transformation is a betrayal of everything fat activists hold dear.Of the , largely positive comments about the star losing an incredible seven stone, some sniped that she looked “unhealthy”and questioned how she lost it — the inference being that she had succumbed to having a gastric band.But as Pete Geracimo, her former personal trainer, points out: “It was never about getting super-skinny. It was about getting her healthy.”Not least, one suspects, for the benefit of her seven-year-old son Angelo. He adds: “She embraced better eating habits and committed to her fitness and ‘is sweating!’ I could not be prouder or happier for her.”Hear hear. Yet alarmingly, research out earlier this year found that millions of women hid their efforts to slim for fear of being mocked or labelled “anti-feminist”.Saints preserve us. The truth, of course, is thatsomeone is deeply insecure about their own weight, they either pooh-pooh or, worse, lash out at the efforts of those who manage to transform their lestyle via willpower and hard slog.Far easier to do that than take a look at our own bad habits and attempt to change them. True, there are plenty of people who look overweight but are physically fit.And there are plenty of skinny malinkies who can’t run for a bus without needing oxygen. At the end of the day, being happy within yourself is not about how you look, but how you feel.Andyou feel that you are unfit thanks to lousy eating habits and lack of exercise, then you should be able to do something about it without being taken to task by those who don’t have the same self-discipline.Particularly as last week’s research from the University of Liverpool found that obesity increased the risk of dying from coronavirus by  per cent. You can’t argue with that.BOREDOM at Moore Towers has reached such a crisis point that, on Sunday, I linked my iPhone to our portable speaker, put the songs on Shuffle and said we had to endure enjoy whatever track came up.At first there were plenty of goodies from Floyd, Bowie, Prefab Sprout and Talk Talk, but then Twinkle Twinkle Little Star popped up, followed by You Spin Me Round by . . . Alvin And The Chipmunks.For the record, our youngest is now . It seems it’s not just the kitchen cupboards that need a clear-out.BRINGING million people out of lockdown was never going to be easy.But Boris’s much-trumpeted grand statement was a damp squib that’s left us as confused as Adam and Eve on Mother’s Day.In a nutshell, four-year-olds will be able go to school with lots of kids they’re not related to but not see other kids in their family, we can go to work with colleagues but not have a chat with them in their garden, we can do unlimited exercise which we could have done anyway,we go abroad we have to self-isolate for a fortnight . . . unless it’s France, and you can drive to other destinations but not too far, whatever that means.As for “stay alert”, is that the same as Police  presenter Shaw Taylor’s old mantra of: “Keep ’em peeled ”Except we could actually see someone coming at us with a crowbar.A virus that can fit squillion times on to the head of a pin might prove harder to spot.GIVEN that the use of face masks is being actively encouraged but not the professional ones needed by key workers, a number of DIY versions are being suggested.Some involve an element of seamstress skills, but for those who want a quick and effective mask they can drum up with the minimum effort, this is my favourite.Loop a child’s hair tieover each end until it resembles a boiled sweet, then fold over the ends to meet in the middle .Then simply place the wrong side against your face, loop the hair ties around your ears, and voila.You’re welcome.FASHION designer Freya Edmondson – daughter of Ab Fab star Jenner Saunders and actor Ade Edmondson – has posted this photo of herself doing a “sumptuous, heart-opening backbend”, while writing on a notepad.Freya, who teaches free online yoga courses, is just  and, therefore, wonderfully flexible.As a former enthusiastic gymnast, it reminds me of my youth, when I would watch TV while doing the box splits – with my legs stretched out at right angles to my body.With my th birthday looming this Sunday,I attempted it now it would take four paramedics and a system of pulleys to get me on my feet again.ACADEMICS may lord it over the rest of us when it comes to quadratic equations, subatomic phenomena or the three components of the epidemiological triangle, but when it comes to common sense they are often found lacking.Quite how “Professor Lockdown” Neil Ferguson thought he could preach to the rest of us about social distancing while inviting his mistress to his house is anyone’s guess, but he did, and now he’s rightly had to resign for hypocrisynothing .He says: “I accept I made an error . . . I thought I was immune.”From Covid- . . . or criticism THE latest series of Killing Eve may have had a lukewarm reception from critics, but central character Villanelle’s fashion choices have been attracting a lot of attention.One frock cost £,, another £,, and her red leather catsuit would set you back an eye-watering £,.I know these are desperate times for all businesses, but since when have fashionistas been clamouring to get their clothes on the back of a psychotic murderer It gives a whole new meaning to “dressed to kill”.HAIRDRESSERS are to stay closed until July  at the earliest.Up to now I have been making do with the occasional fringe cut using a pair of nail scissors.But given that my “style”is supposed to be choppy bob, and I now resemble Richard lll, it seems I will have to tackle the rest of it too.Worse, The Bloke will have to do the back and, God forbid, baldlygo where no man has gone before.Our journalists strive for title: us nuclear bombers fly europe show force china russia
story: AMERICA’S strategic nuclear bomber squadrons have been in the sky over the Indo-Pacic region and Europe — to show they are ready to strike despite the coronavirus pandemic.In a massive show of strength, the US Air Force has flown all three types of its bomber aircraft on long-range missions over the past week.The B- Spirit stealth bomber, the B-H Stratofortress and the B-B Lancer are all capable of carrying nuclear tipped bombs and cruise missiles. USAF in Europe and Air Forces Africa commander General Jeffrey L. title: new born baby boy eaten monitor lizards
story: The infant was discovered by a group of boys who went to play by the waterside in Nakhon Si Thammarat, southern Thailand.Nong Ake, , reported the find on Monday to a security guard. The child told police he smelled something strange then noticed a black bag next to the pond, which he went to look at.The youngster said he saw the dead infant inside and the babys internal organs had been ripped out.Police arrived and found the baby had been dead for one or two days. They believe the bite wounds on the infants body were from monitor lizards, which live in the pond and normally eat fish and scraps of food from bins.But officers are now investigating whether the newborn baby boy was abandoned while he was still alive and then eaten by the lizards orthe leless body was dumped there and then the scavenging reptiles started to bite at the corpse.They are carnivorous and often consume large insects and spiders, other lizards, small mammals, fish, mollusks, and birds. These lizards do not surprise their prey, they actively pursue their prey  them by swimming, climbing, or running after them. They also eat corpses of human beings, which they have been known to excavate and devour.Thailand has a large population of monitor lizards. The large reptiles can be spotted in ponds, rivers, lakes, mangroves, and swamps, slinking through parks and forests, basking on tree branches, scavenging through piles of rubbish, and sometimes crossing busy roads right in the middle of town.Please can you inset this  into the bottom left  Police Major Colonel Jittakorn Konglhue said the babys body will undergo a thorough post-mortem examination and DNA tests to try and match the family.He said: We believe that the cruel mother left her baby by the pond before it was attacked by the monitor lizards.We will check the CCTV around the area to try to identy the mother and arrest her immediately.The babys corpse is now at the hospital to undergo a post-mortem examination to check whether they were alive or dead when they were eaten by the reptiles.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits flock beauty spots tourist bosses stay away
story: BRITS have been flocking to beauty spots today despite some tourist bosses urging them to stay away during the coronavirus lockdown.Tourists were seen heading to scenic areas and beaches across the country after the Government gave the green light for travel for unlimited exercise.Tourists and nature lovers were spotted heading to iconic spots across the country, such as the Lake District and Ilkley Moor near Bradford.While some areas, such as Dorsets Durdle Door, are welcoming visitors, many have said they wont be welcoming tourists despite the easing of restrictions.Cornwall, Cumbria and the Cotswolds were among some of the regions which have said they wouldnt be welcoming tourists yet despite the lockdown easing.And Blackpool has even begged tourists to stay away, using its chief executive Richard Leafe said: For now, were asking people not to rush back to the Lake District - help protect our communities, the fells will still be here when this passes.Boris Johnson beach, parks and lakes that are not nearby.But they must stay within England and cannot cross the border into Wales or Scotland.Nicola Sturgeon warned anyone crossing over could face arrest, too.But shortly after the address, Cumbrias tourism board tweeted: We are shocked by the timing and short notice of tonights announcement.We are awaiting further details but the safety of residents must come by Prime Minister Johnsons statement regarding the easing of travel restrictions.We believe this could have severe implications for Cumbria, for our NHS and for those who live in the county.Cumbria has one of the highest infection rates for coronavirus in the UK.The arrival of many day visitors could easily compromise all the really good work that has been done to date to manage the current county for a day visit.There is nowhere to stay. There are very limited places to eat, other than takeaways.At this time we ask you to stay away, and in the comfort of your own home, plan a future break to Cornwall when it is safe to do so.Nancy Platts, leader of Brighton and Hove City Council, said: We want a slow, steady and safe progression towards lockdown lting.The council released a statement, saying: We want to make sure we are stepping forward in a measured way. We know restrictions will need to stay in place for a long time to come.We want the restrictions to be lted carefully in a positive direction. title: hairdressers bulk buy bleach mobile services lockdown
story: HAIRDRESSERS are bulk buying bleaches and dyes to meet overwhelming demand for styling during lockdown.Thousands of crimpers are getting hair care products delivered to their homes.Many are carrying out trims wearing masks and gloves.Some stylists are even advertising mobile services.It comes as many people do DIY makeovers, including singer Dua Lipa, who has dyed her black and blonde hair red.Hairdressing for anyone other than a household member is forbidden under lockdown rules.One professional body urged ministers to apply the ban on salons and barbers “to the sector as a whole” — and pleaded with the public not to fuel demand.But thousands of hair care orders were being processed at the Coty Wella distribution centre in Basingstoke, Hants.Some staff are on furlough but a core remain.Parcels are delivered by UPS.An industry source said: “After lockdown demand for salon professional products fell off a clf before hairdressers started ordering small tubs of bleach and dye but it’s rocketed.“We’re getting giant orders from hairdressers and it can’t all be for them.“There’s no doubt they’re working from home. title: flu jabs every brit coronavirus
story: EVERY Brit should be given a flu jab to help stop the NHS being overwhelmed this winter, ministers have been told.The idea is being mooted by government scientists who fear a second wave of Covid during the coldest months will overrun hospitalsit coincides with a major outbreak of seasonal flu.Flu kills , Brits a year and can take up to , ward beds in winter.Government advisers have asked ministers to urgently look into vaccinating all age groups to try to protect the NHS from a double-whammy.The recommendations were made after a Sage meeting last month, The Sun understands.Currently, fewer than half of people in England are eligible for the free flu jab.The nation’s top doctor has already warned the NHS would struggle to cope with a surge in coronavirus during its busiest time of year.Chief medical officer Professor Chris Whitty said it would be far more dficult to manage coronavirus when people had coughs and colds, as the symptoms were similar.He said work was under way to see how it would spread in the coldest months — and find ways to combat it.Prof Whitty added: “At this point in the yearsomeone’s got something that looks like Covid there’s a high chance it is Covid. In the winter, that is less true.”Government scientists now want ministers to consider universal flu vaccination and Department of Health officials are urgently looking at the idea.About million people in England are currently eligible. They include OAPs, pregnant women, young children and those with underlying medical conditions.Professor Robert Dingwall, who sits on Nervtag, which feeds into Sage, said: “It would seem to be a sensible strategy and it also has benefits to the economy by reducing sickness absence, alongside the benefits of the NHS not having to treat a lot of people with influenza and Covid-.”The jab is also available privately from pharmacies and costs £..But Prof Dingwall, who has had no involvement in the plans, said the Government needed to decide in the next week — or risk facing supply problems.He said it could cost £million but that it would be a sound investment.Nigel Edwards, chief executive of Nuffield Trust, said: “A big second wave of Covid coupled with bad flu would leave the NHS struggling. title: testing positive coronavirus contacts traced

title: itll do our spoiled young remainers good to remain in britain for the summer holidays
story: STRANGE though it sounds, I felt a little gleeful when I heard the news that ­foreign summer holidays will not be going ahead this year.Of course my heart goes out to all the hard-working ­parents longing for a week in the European sunshine with their families.But I can’t help thinking a summer spent in Britain will do our spoiled ­metropolitan ­millennials a world of good.Why  Because having spent their formative years jet-setting around the world, far too many of them are mind-bogglingly and unashamedly stupid about their own country.Take my old university ­flatmate as an example.After “gap-yearing” in ­Borneo and Bali, he turned up in the ancient, bustling city of York laden with so much fancy ­coffee making equipment it looked like he was carrying the whole of Starbucks on his back.When questioned, he casually revealed that as a born and bred Londoner he’d never travelled north of Wembley before — and wasn’t quite surecafes existed “up here”.He’s not the only one.Living in London over the past five years, I’ve met a postgraduate student who ­confused Birmingham with Newcastle , a globe-trotting teenager who thought Glastonbury was in Wales, and — most bizarrely of all — a confident young lawyer utterly convinced that the Lake District was a fictional place.On the face of it, their ­ignorance is laughable. And I’ll admit, I didn’t correct the ­lawyer .But there’s a darker side to it. A generation of young city dwellers who know nothing about Britain were always bound to underestimate our four great nations.And so they did in the  referendum.The overlap between London and the Remain campaign has been well documented —  per cent of the capital voted in favour of remaining in the EU.Among London’s student population, the depth of ­support for the EU was overwhelming.And with some ultra-liberal friends, there were moments when it would have seemed easier to come out as a ­paedophile than a Brexiteer.Of course, ardent young Remainers convinced themselves that their love of the European Union was borne out of a sophisticated appreciation of all things global.But it seems more likely to me that they saw the EU as the ­saviour to a backwards, grisly country they imagined in their ignorance to be Britain.This summer, that ignorance could finally be shattered.Thanks to Covid-, the nation’s young people won’t have the option of scurrying to ­Heathrow the second their uni exams are over.Instead —they want holidays at all — they’ll be minibreaking in Manchester or camping in the English countryside.Yes, they might turn their noses up at rolling hills, stunning architecture and incredible free museums.But I have a sneaking suspicion they’ll be surprised and impressed with what they find beyond the confines of the M.And, reconnected to their roots at last, they might just begin to feel the first stirrings of patriotism running through their British veins.When the Government published its new guidelines for lockdown in England, I – like the rest of Twitter – found myself getting very worked up about whether or not I’m allowed to play tennis with someone outside of my household.The problem, as my mum gently reminded me, is that in my case it’s a bit of a moot point: I’ve never played tennis before and I’m not entirely sure how to hold a racket.I doubt either my housemate or my friends will be begging for a game any time soon.IT’S not often I find myself welling up at the radio. But LBC caller Liz, from Witham, Essex, got me in the gut this week.Through uncontrollable tears, she explained thatcoronavirus didn’t kill her, being forbidden from touching her grand-children surely would.She’s not alone. After nearly two gruelling months of lockdown, millions of us are experiencing real, gut-wrenching loneliness.They don’t like to complain – they know their suffering is dwarfed by that of frontline health and care staffers. But starved of the company of those they love, they are withering like plants out of sunshine.You’d expect a Conservative government instinctively to get this. For generations, Tory MPs have told us that family is crucially important to the ing of the UK.They’ve thrown their weight behind policies designed to strengthen families and made many moving speeches about how a family unit is more than the sum of its parts.But it seems all that was just for show. For in their admirable haste to propel Brits back to work, this Government seems to have forgotten about families altogether.Boris Johnson’s Sunday night speech – stuffed full of specic advice for workers – didn’t have a single word of hope for single adult relatives craving each other’s company.And the millions of young adults longing to know when they can next hug Mum will have been bitterly disappointed.Of course, the PM is right to say we need to get the economy going again.Forecasts from the Treasury on the upcoming recession could hardly be more alarming – and despite the best efforts of Chancellor Rishi Sunak and his bailouts, millions of businesses will go bustthey can’t get up and running again soon.Butwe’re expected to get up close with colleagues for the sake of the economy, surely we should get to see those we love best for the sake of our mental health The people of Britain are humans, not cash cows. Andthey are to get through this long, draining war in one piece, they need the support of the people they love.LISTENING to BBC News anchor Fiona Bruce casually describe carers as “low-skilled workers” really set my teeth on edge.To the shame of this nation, care home staff are indeed low paid.But low skilled  I reckon plenty of them would be more than capable of reading the news from an autocue for £, a year.And I’d like to see cofed Fiona feed, clean and comfort a newly widowed dementia sufferer without losing her cool.FOR the best part of the past decade, bespectacled “experts” gravely predicted that online dating would kill romance.Apps – they told us – would transform the dating scene into an endless virtual marketplace where singles could shop for each other , or  would turn dating into a minimal-effort pursuit of on-demand hook ups .How wrong they were.Rather than bonking their way round new digital acquaintances, millennial Brits in the st Century spend their downtime uploading photos and biographies to their smartphones and earnestly looking for love.And my, do they succeed.Last year a whopping  per cent of newly married couples met online, and Hinge – the dating app geared towards lelong relationships – is gaining users faster than any of its competitors.Granted, these apps aren’t perfect.We all like a good romance story, and Dad messaging Mum with a winky face because he liked her bikini selfie is hardly the stuff of Hollywood.But now that flirting in the pub is a thing of the past, let’s thank our lucky stars that the country’s poor singles have a shot at love at all.Rather than sitting on the sofa twiddling their thumbs, furloughed folk have been busy sculpting, chiselling and painting – and selling the fruits of their labours online.These plucky, small-time entrepreneurs are the very best of Britain.And with them around, I have no doubt this country will be back on its feet in no time.I’M absolutely loving Normal People on BBC.The chemistry between Marianneand Connellis really quite something.And as an ode to young love, the whole thing is pitch-perfect.In fact, my only quibble is why on earth are all the characters so darn sophisticated They’re , for goodness sake.Let’s see fewer candle-lit, red wine-soaked dinner parties and more tins of warm Foster’s. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: benidorms iconic tiki bar quiet
story: The famous Costa Blanca watering hole - now re-named Aloha Beach Bar - is said to have taken over a bar next door so holidaymakers can enjoy their booze whilst maintaining a sensible distance.Footage of the deserted strip has immerged, showing empty bar terraces and silent streets.The video of the usually packed-out strip shows just how hard the party spot has been hit by the Covid- pandemic.Sizzling pavements awash with boozed-up holidaymakers seem to be a distant memory for this part of Spain as the streets fall silent.Spain imposed a strict lockdown following the spread of the coronavirus, which has killed more than , people.In September o, judges had ordered the closure of the ‘controversial’ fun pub devastating thousands of holidaymakers and fun-loving locals.The hugely-popular bar was ordered to close for good following years of complaints from bleary-eyed neighbours.It was a massive favourite with Brits for daytime as well as evening boozing until the courts called time on the bar.But in March last year the bar reopened without an official name, with former England and Spurs ace Paul Gascoigne seen partying with boozers there in JulyToday, Jacqui Perkins, who runs Facebook group Benidorm  Costa Blanca News  Information Forum, announced the bar formerly known as Tiki Beach had taken over the bar next to it.Jackqui posted: So some news for you all.Tiki is extending!!! title: mcdonalds coronavirus cluster doubles overnight aussie
story: A CLUSTER of coronavirus cases in a McDonalds in Australia has doubled overnight as the UK prepares to open the restaurant for drive-thru and delivery.Three further employees at the fast-food establishment in Melbourne have now tested positive for the deadly disease.It comes after three employees at the restaurant in Fawkner, North Melbourne, were confirmed to have tested positive yesterday.The number could yet shoot up, with the test results of all  employees yet to .The first to be diagnosed fell ill in April but stayed home, followed by a second staff member diagnosed on Friday after working one sht.A third staff member was then struck down with the killer bug on Tuesday, Victorias Department of Health and Human Services reports.Health chiefs are now working with McDonalds to make sure the correct actions are taken, news.au says.The restaurant has now reopened following a deep clean, and it is being staffed by employees from other outlets in the region.Those in direct contact with the infected workers have been told to quarantine for  days.The state of Victoria has now recorded , cases of the virus, as lockdown restrictions are eased with many Aussies allowed back into parks and beaches.The states health department said on Saturday: There is no evidence Covid- can be transmitted to people through food or packaging, and the risk of anyone visiting the McDonalds contracting the virus is very low.However, anyone with even mild symptoms should get tested and self-isolate until the results are known.McDonalds said cleanliness is its priority, as well as keeping staff and the community safe.It comes as the restaurant plans to reopen  drive-thrus next Wednesday across the UK - title: speaker lindsay hoyle demands safety
story: NewsSpeaker Lindsay Hoyle demands safety first as Government pushes for MPs’ The Commons Speaker said everyone on the parliamentary estate must be kept safe and social distancing rules must be complied withShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsSir Lindsay said he would be led by Public Health England on social distancing " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSir Lindsay Hoyle has insisted he will suspend Commons proceedingsthey get too crowded after the Government pressed for MPs towithin weeks. The Commons Speaker said everyone on the parliamentary estate must be kept safe and social distancing rules must be complied with. The requirement for two metres between people means only  MPs can attend the chamber in person, while up to  can join proceedings remotely via Zoom. Sir Lindsay told MPs: My priority and the priority of all, Iaposm sure, is to ensure that those on the estate are safe while business is facilitated. Iaposm working with parties, the Commission, to ensure this duty of care is taken seriously. Nothing in the Leaderaposs announcement changes the position on social distancing in and around the chamber and throughout the parliamentary estate – only changes to the guidance from Public Health England can do that.”It came as Boris Johnson backed Jacob Rees-Mogg as he urged MPs toto Parliament despite the coronavirus lockdown.People have been told to work from home where possible – and MPs have been taking part in virtual debates over video link for weeks. But Commons Leader Mr Rees-Mogg infuriated opposition parties by they should “lead by example” in going back to Westminster. He said: It is clear that soon Parliament must set an example of how we move back gradually to a fully-ing country again. “Our constituents would expect nothing less. “So while we must move in step with public health guidance, it is vital that when we are asking other people to work and go to their places of workthey cannot do so from home we should not be the ones who are exempt from that.  “Indeed, we should be leading by example. Prospect union deputy general secretary Garry Graham branded the announcement “extremely worrying for all those working in Parliament who have as much right as anyone to be kept safe during this pandemic”. He added: “The example it would be setting by adopting this approach would be to undermine the Government’s first rule that those who can work from home should continue to do so. “Having more MPs on site would mean hundreds more staff who are currently working safely from home would be needed in Parliament there has so far been no risk assessment factoring in increasing numbers of MPs and staff.” But No backed Mr Rees-Mogg, with the Prime Ministeraposs spokesman saying: “Itaposs vital that Parliament can continue to scrutinise the Government and legislate to support the coronavirus response. “The existing, temporary arrangements limit some of these s – that is why work is ongoing by the House authorities in step with the public health advice to carefully move back to more ordinary business and have more political proceedings in the House.” “The Government supports those efforts and, in line with health advice, MPs should be encouraged to come back to Westminster once arrangements are in place.”

Had the governmentaposs actual plan for lting lockdown been pitched to a studio boss, it would have been rejected as too farcical even for Partridge. It reads like Hunter S. Thompson had spent a week on laughing gas, then topped up with Sunny Delight. The rules - and these are all genuine - include:. Granny may NOT enter your house to see her grandchildren. If you pay her to be their nanny then she CAN.. You MAY ask the housekeeper Mrs Miggins toto work polishing the family silver in the downstairs pantry, but you may NOT allow her to enter your house for reasons other than domestic drudgery.. You MUST go to work, unless you do NOT want to go to work. . You should NOT use public transport. You MUST cycle, walk or drive wherever possible. This MAY, or may NOT, include the M. . You MAY share a car with someone from outside your household to get to work, sitting within a metre of them, so long as you have all windows down at ALL TIMES . You may NOT sit within a metre of that same person in your own house, EVEN IF all the windows are open. . You must NOT look directly at anyone while using public transport .. If you are going to be in enclosed spaces other than a car share, or a downstairs pantry while instructing staff, you SHOULD wear a mask made from a t-shirt you no longer want. If you make it from a t-shirt you DO want, you MAY find it no longer fits. . You MAY go to France, but not on holiday. You MAY play team sports but only with members of your own household, which limits most people to a hand of whist unless, like our illustrious Prime Minister, you have sired enough children to stage your own World Cup. . You MAY travel wherever you like within the UK, with the exception of three massive chunks of it called Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. DO NOT GO THERE. . If you live on one side of a border and work on the other, youaposre basically f***ed, arenapost you. . You MAY stand metres apart from your mum and dad outside the supermarket and all have a good old natter. You may NOT do the same in a park. . You MAY see your mum, OR your dad, in the park for a socially-distanced picnic, but not both of them at once. Your mum and dad MAY go to the park for a picnic together. Your household MAY go to the same park for a picnic and sit next to them. You may NOT talk to each other. . You MAY sit m apart from someone in the park, but NOT in your own garden.. You MUST avoid crowds, but you MAY soongo to weddings.  . The risk of death from Covid- to people under  will be assumed to DEPEND on their underlying health conditions. . The risk of death for everyone over  will be assumed to be IMMINENT, eventhey ran a marathon, fathered a baby, or won a drinking contest in the past week. . Graphs will be supplied to help you understand things. There will be NO numbers on these graphs. . You SHOULD wash your clothes often, even though the Prime Minister seems to wear the same suit for a week.. Having spent  decades complaining about OPEN borders, and bugger the financial and logistical arguments for having them, on being presented with a genuine reason to close them this government didnapost, because of the financial and logistical arguments. As we prepare to open up the country, we will CLOSE the borders. . This rule does NOT apply to our border with the Republic of Ireland, which we still havenapost got our heads around. . We gave you LOTS of money we donapost have. We want it back. Evenyou lost your job, or are a nurse. There will be no austerity, and we will invest money in a greener, healthier future, although CHRIST knows where the moneyaposs coming from. . We are very AWARE of the mental and social costs to the disabled of being shut away in their own homes without human contact for months at a time, but granny can LUMP it. We will make sure health outcomes are not affected disproportionately, even though weaposve already had , excess non-coronavirus deaths so this was a lie before we wrote it, just like the one we wrote about how people in care homes wouldnapost get infected and werenapost our problem.

title: dog amazing animal litter iams
story: AdvertorialLabrador Molly becomes celebrity in seaside town thanks to her unique talentDetermined pooch has become famous for picking up litter on her local beach with proud owner FlissShareByDave Masters:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY Advertorial" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA littler-picking labrador has proved sheaposs a true retriever after collecting , pieces of rubbish from her local beach. Pooch Molly has developed such a special bond with owner Fliss she has been able to train her to find plastic bottles, ropes, spades, buckets, and toys. And the inseparable duo have become famous in Scarborough for their ongoing efforts cleaning up the coastline  days a year. Hailing her furry friend, Fliss, , said: I can’t take credit for her great work, she’s the best dog and it’s really just the way she is. She’s my best bud, we work together, live together, play together, she’s at my side literally all the time. If I spent this much time with a human we would have fallen out by now, but the bond between a dog and their owner just gets stronger over time.  She’s super chilled, always up for an adventure and has to say hello to every single person and dog she meets. Molly is just a brilliant dog, I often wonder how I got so lucky, she has a beautul, happy soul and has changed my le for the better. The funny thing is she still doesn’t know the dference between an empty discarded bottle and a bottle that is still full which has led to some interesting situations. She’ll sometimes come back to me with a full bottle and I’ll look across the beach and there’ll be a confused person wondering why this dog has just stolen their drink. Her intentions are good though, and she’s just trying to do the right thing. Thankfully no one ever gets angry because she’s so cute!  Fliss said Molly picks up so many pieces of litter every day, the items have started to take over her home and workplace. She explained: I could probably fill a wheelie bin every week or two with what we collect. At one point my garage was probably % filled with beach litter waiting to be distributed to local artists for use in artwork sculptures etc. I also save any buckets spades beach toys that can be reused, and let tourists borrow them for the day - so my shop also has a couple of hundred of these which takes up quite a bit of space.Fliss has shared her inspiring story as part of IAMSapos latest campaign celebrating the magic of pets and the iniduality of each animal. She said Molly loves tucking into her breakfast bowl before a busy day doing her extra special job for the community.  Itaposs so important to give dogs a healthy, nutritious and balanced diet, which will keep them going all day! she told us. Molly needs it when sheaposs up and down the beach - the exercise is great for her as well.  IAMS champion the joy of your pet’s healthy vitality. Itaposs not simply visible health or your dog’s happiness it is a powerful combination of the two together. And that’s why IAMS want to help the nation’s pets live healthy, active and happy lives through the expert nutrition they truly enjoy. No compromise. Fliss moved to the seaside in  where she opened a bath and skincare shop - but she couldn’t believe how much litter she found left senselessly on the beach and said she was shocked and appalled by the “unavoidable” amount of litter she found while taking Molly for walks She added: Mollyaposs such a good girl and she’s never had any issues unless she spots a tennis ball - tennis balls take precedence over everything.  We get stopped all the time by people who think it’s adorable that she’s cleaning. She gets so much attention and she loves it, she knows she’s a bit of a star. Unfortunately Molly can’t clean the beach on her own, but she’s trying. We want to get people involved or at least make them think twice before disposing of their litter so carelessly.

title: boy 5 returns home after
story: NewsBoy, , s home after receiving first of its kind double lung transplant in UKEXCLUSIVE: Joseph Nicholson was kept alive at Freeman and Great North Children’s Hospital in Newcastle with a special oxygen machine while waiting for the le saving operationShareCommentsByJeremy Armstrong:,  MAY NewsJoseph Nicholson is now back at home following the operation" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA brave little boy is back home after the first double lung transplant of its kind carried out in the UK. Doctors used a special oxygen machine to keep Joseph Nicholson alive while they waited for an organ donor. Called extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, it uses a pump to circulate blood through an articial lung that oxygenates the blood. Doctors kept Joseph on it continuously until his operation – the first time that had been done in this country. In his nine-month stay at Freeman and Great North Children’s Hospital in Newcastle, Joseph celebrated his fth birthday with parents Fiona and Gary. Fiona, a teacher of Catterick, in North Yorkshire, said: “It’s been a rollercoaster. Throughout it, we’ve tried really hard not to think past the next day. “We didn’t want to panic, to think about worst-case scenarios. “Every time we spoke to the doctors we focused on what was the next step to getting Joseph better.” After receiving his new lungs from a donor in Europe, the youngster is ready to continue his “phenomenal journey”, according to paediatric respiratory physician Matthew Thomas. And yesterday Fiona and accountant Gary, both , enjoyed their first full day at home with Joseph, who is autistic, and his little brother, Henry. “We want to thank the hospital staff for everything,” they said. “All the team, Matt, [Dr] Malcolm Brodlie and surgeons – they have been absolutely wonderful, and are our heroes.”.” Until last summer, Joseph was a healthy boy who loved toy trains.  After developing what appeared to be mild pneumonia, he deteriorated rapidly and progressed to profound lung failure. Following aggressive and extensive treatment, it became clear Joseph would die without a lung transplant. ECMO is used at a handful of centres to care for babies and children suffering severe heart or respiratory failure. But it is rarely used as a bridge to lung transplantation, and the approach had not been successfully tried in the UK. Joseph’s story comes days before Mirror-backed Max and Keira’s law on organ donation comes into force. It means from May , all adults in England will be assumed to be donors when they die, unless they opt out. And Joseph’s parents want to raise awareness about donation, especially in children. Fiona said: “We never realised it could be months before a suitable donor was found but we were lucky and will always be thankful. It was a miracle, really.” With the country in lockdown, Joseph, who is still on ventilation and has a tracheostomy, will isolate at home. Both parents ided their time between hospital wards and the Sick Children’s Trust, which provides accommodation for families of poorly children.
