story: A GALASHIELS postman has been wearing a superhero costume while delivering parcels.James Morley, , of Melrose, raises a chuckle on his round by donning an Iron Man suit with his high-vis vest.Mr Morley said: "If people smile or laugh because of me, thats all I wanted."The stunt has been particularly popular with older residents, according to Mr Morley.He said: "Older people are at home and havent been able to see their grandchildren and families."A lot of them wanted the photos so they could say that Iron Man delivered their post."Ive had people whove missed me asking me to come back round again so they can get photos and their children can see me through the window."But Mr Morley, based at Galashiels Delivery Office, might not be the only superhero postie in town for much longer.He told the Border : "I may have convinced colleagues to join me. Were trying to organise a day when we can all dress up."Most of my colleagues, when I said I was going to do this, they didnt believe me until I walked into the office."It is unclear whether other members of the Marvel Avengers will join Mr Morley, but some residents are already suggesting he showcase other superheroes, including Spiderman and Batman.For now, however, Mr Morley and his colleagues ndash in costume or not ndash are continuing to provide their key service in abnormal circumstances."Our job has changed drastically," Mr Morley said. "In some respects its easier, leaving parcels at the door for contactless deliveries, but its a bit like Christmas as everyones at home so theyre ordering more as they cant go out."Its like Christmas but with fewer staff, too."Were just trying our best to press on with bringing parcels and letters to people."If you know of any other key workers going above and beyond to improve peoples days during lockdown, get in touch by emailing editorial@bordertelegraph or by messaging our Facebook page at www.facebook bordertelegraph

title: melrose-shops-praise-volunteers-free-deliveries-start
story: TRADERS in Melrose have joined forces to offer free delivery to customers who are unable to leave their homes.Butcher Martin Baird, , has recruited a raft of volunteer drivers to serve products from his shop and three others.Mr Baird said customer feedback has been ldquogreat, adding: ldquoWe had nearly  deliveries today ndash itrsquos really gone bananas.Other businesses taking part in the scheme are the Country Kitchen Deli, the Premier newsagent and vegetable shop Purple Plum.Mr Baird, whose shop has been on the high street for  years, said at least  people have volunteered to deliver.ldquoI try to give them payment, but they wonrsquot accept it ndash so I just give them a bit of meat, he told the Border .Drop-offs are being made in Galashiels almost every day, said Mr Baird, with some households in Stow, Bowden and Kelso also seeking help.Mr Baird said his business has always been popular, but demand has shot up during the coronavirus lockdown.He said: ldquoIrsquove taken on a couple of youngsters just for this period andthis keeps up, I might have to employ a couple more, because I canrsquot keep working  hours a week.Ready-made meals are proving to be a major hit, Mr Baird said. Big sellers include roast beef, lasagne and sweet and sour dishes.ldquoThe amount of mince Irsquove sold is just incredible. And wersquove got a full-time pie man and hersquos just having to work his socks off, Mr Baird said, adding: ldquoWersquore the lucky ones, being busy ndash I feel for some people.In a joint statement, the four shop owners said they are ldquoincredibly thankful for the help provided by volunteers.Commending their efforts, the statement added: ldquoThey are actively committed to continuing to provide this essential doorstep service to all those who require it.

title: jack-lowden-invites-entries-earlston-high-talent-show
story: ACTOR Jack Lowden has urged pupils at Earlston High School to take part in a talent competition.The former Earlston student starred in a video on Facebook this week appealing for entries to Earlstonrsquos Got Virtual Talent.Lowden invited pupils to submit video clips of themselves doing "something really cool and extraordinary".The -second clips should be sent through Show My Homework, he said, between May  and June .Giving examples of the talent being sought, Lowden said performances may showcase cooking, acting, singing, dancing, football skills or dog routines.When entries are received, judges will whittle them down to a shortlist and then the public will vote for the winner."There will be an almighty bonanza of a prize for the person that wins," said Lowden, calling on pupils to "have some fun".Lowden, who received an Olivier Award in , has appeared in films including Dunkirkand Mary, Queen of Scots.

title: mays-super-flower-moon-see-uk
story: A so-called lsquoFlower Moonrsquo will be spotted over the skies of the UK this week.Not only that, but Mays full moon will also be a supermoon, making it a Super Flower Moon.But just what does all that mean What is a Flower Moon The May full moon is traditionally known as the Flower Moon simply because it appears at the time of blossoming flowers.What is a supermoon The moon - our planets only natural satellite - actually follows an elliptical orbit around the Earth.This means that at certain points on its egg-shaped path, it can be further away, or closer to us - a dferential of about , miles.The closest point is called the perigee, and the furthest is the apogee. When a full moon falls on the perigee, it appears far bigger and brighter in the sky and becomes known as a supermoon.The phenomenon is not actually that rare, and this months is last in a trilogy that began with Marchs full moon..During a supermoon,the diameter of the moon canappear to be about  per cent greater than an average full moon.What timewill the moon be biggest The full moon will be in the night sky on the evening of Thursday, May , though it will technically be at its fullest at :am on Thursday morning.Seeing as it wont even be in the sky then - let alone visible in daylight - the fullest youll get to see the moon will come at around .pm on Thurday, when the moon rises.It will be in the sky all night, and wont set again until about .am the following morning, offering plenty of time for you to catch a glimpse.For the best effect ndash and the closest yoursquoll get to witnessing the spectacular images seen across social media following such an event ndash yoursquoll want to look east shortly after moonrise.ldquoWhen the moon is near the horizon, it can look unnaturally large when viewed through trees, buildings, or other foreground objects," say NASA."The effect is an optical illusion, but that fact doesnrsquot take away from the experience."What  should I look out for This months full moon ties in nicely with the peak of the Eta Aquariids meteor shower.The meteor shower has been going on above our heads for a couple of weeks, and runs roughly from April  - May .However, it is this week when budding astronomers are likely to get the best show, as the shower peaks on the night of May  into May .The Eta Aquariids should be visible with the naked eye, although the glare from a full supermoon will make them harder to spot.Those living in built up areas would usually be advised to travel to less populated spaces and to avoid light pollutionthey really want to see the shower, but with ongoing lockdown restrictions and the coronavirus pandemic, that is not advised.Wrapping up in warm clothes is recommended, and you should allow up to  minutes for your eyes to fully adjust to the night sky.The Eta Aquariids are not one of the years most spectacular meteor showers, and usually peak at around  meteors per hours - thats just under one a minute.

title: caring-woman-guarding-door-borders-chemist
story: WHEN the Peebles Fat Face store closed its doors along with every other shop on the High Street, assistant manager Jane McGarry wasnrsquot home for long before going back to work.No sooner had she hung up the closed sign, Jane began a new voluntary post at a vital store directly opposite.She explained: ldquoWe closed on the Saturday before lockdown. I saw a post for help in Boots chemist on the COVID support page on the Monday morning and was in Boots an hour later.Janersquos new role involves manning the door of the chemist as people queue to pick up medicines.ldquoI roughly do five or six hours a day, Monday to Saturday," she said."My main role is basically to make sure I only let two people in the shop at a time.ldquoThe public are great and understanding. I also take repeat prescriptions so people donrsquot have to queue.Jane joked that she probably now knows the layout in Boots better than she does in Fat Face.ldquoIrsquom getting to know where things are in the shop so I can assist people," she said, adding: ldquoIt feels great to do my bit, evenit is just a cheery face or a friendly hello."While Jane helps people by handing in prescriptions, Peebles student Annie Patterson has proved a dab hand at delivering them.Annie is studying veterinary nursing at Edinburgh Napier University and was due to start her summer placement before the coronavirus outbreak.She said: ldquoAt the beginning of the pandemic, I saw that the NHS was recruiting volunteers throughout the UK."I asked Danielle at Bootsthey needed a hand delivering prescriptions. I wanted to use this time I now had available to help others.ldquoI have been doing this Monday to Saturday for six weeks now and itrsquos great because the majority of people are so grateful."

title: 65th-anniversary-couple-met-galashiels-academy
story: A COUPLE will celebrate their th anniversary today by speaking to family over Zoom.Charlie and Evelyn Renton, of St Boswells, were married on May , , at Melrose Parish Church.With coronavirus restrictions in place, a traditional family reunion is not possible ndash but the pair have been looking forward to a virtual get-together.Reflecting on their long marriage, Mrs Renton, , said: ldquoWersquove been very happy and healthy and very lucky.The couple, who first met at Galashiels Academy, moved from Mr Rentonrsquos native Galashiels to the Republic of Ireland in .Mrs Renton, originally from Melrose, had qualied as a nurse in Edinburgh, while Mr Renton, , enjoyed a career as a textile designer.The couple have three children , three grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.They ed to the Borders in , moving into their current home in St Boswells.

title: ve-day-75th-anniversary-2-coin-much-may-worth---get-one
story: To mark the th anniversary of VE Day -the Royal Mint has released a commemorative pound coin.Hereseverything you need to know about the new collection from the Royal Mint - including how to get your hands on a coin and how much it costs.Why has the Royal Mint made a commemorative coin The Royal Mint website says: ldquoSeventy-fiveyears on [from VE Day], we thank the generation who gave so much and honour their spirit and sacrice.VE Day stands for Victory in Europe Day, and it refers to May , , when Germany surrendered their armed forces during World War II.The coin from the Royal Mint aims to ldquoremember the first hopeful steps towards lasting peace and the promise of a brighter future.The isional director of commemorative coins at the Royal Mint, Clare Maclennan, said that she hoped the VE Day coins would bring Britain together during the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Maclennan said: ldquoOur VE Day commemorative coin was inspired by a shared sense of community and loyalty.ldquoDuring these challenging times that the nation finds itself in, we may be unable to join with our loved ones to mark this national milestone, but it feels especially important that we come together to protect the older generation that sacriced so much for us.What coins are available to buy If you want to get your hands on the commemorative pound coin from the Royal Mint, you have a few options.The th anniversary of VE Day pound uncirculated coin comes in educational packaging all about VE Day and Winston Churchill. This costs pound.There is also the th anniversary of VE Day silver proof pound coin. This coin is limited edition, with only , made. It costs pound..Next is the th anniversary of VE Day piedfort silver pound coin. Also limited edition, only , have been made. This coin costs pound.Last is the th anniversary of VE Day gold proof pound coin. This is also an extremely limited edition coin, as only  were made. This coin costs pound,.Alternatively, you can purchase a th anniversary of VE Day gold proof pound coin with a period newspaper, which allows you to read the news of VE Day as it was reported from an original period newspaper.This is an extremely limited edition package with only  available to buy. It costs pound, and because itrsquos so rare, yoursquoll need to phone The Royal Mint on    to place an order.For each coin purchased, a donation will be made to the Imperial War Museums.What do the coins look like The coins feature a design which shows the celebrating public with the word lsquovictoryrsquo across the top.Designer Dominique Evans said: ldquoIconic images of VE Day serve to remind us of the magnitude of events.ldquoMillions came together in the streets to celebrate the end of the war in Europe, inspiring me to put the people at the very heart of this coin. The rays evoke search lights, a familiar sight in the skies during wartime, except here they represent rays of home.

title: historic-borders-house-needs-20k-planned-re-opening
story: A STATELY home in the Borders needs pound, so it can re-open to the public in the summer, according to trustees.Paxton House, in Berwickshire, has been closed since the beginning of the coronavirus lockdown in March.But now the Paxton Trust is urging the public to donate by June  so the th century estate can open its doors again in July.Trust chairman Ian Marrian said: ldquoWe want to re-open as soon as itrsquos safe for all and wersquoll have to invest to ensure that safety."We cannot compromise on the conservation of our nationally signicant collections and the glorious natural landscape."But every day without income makes survival a greater challenge."Mr Marrian said the trust is also working "extremely hard" to try to gain a grant to cover the essential running costs for .He added: "We hope that,and when we re-open, we can with your help and attendance make these strange times a little happier.The trust, which has earmarked July  for re-opening, says it needs pound, by the start of the summer to maintain the property, as well as the childrenrsquos playground and gardens.The house was gted to the nation in  by John David Home Robertson, the last laird, for the populations "benefit and enjoyment".Its collection of paintings includes work by Allan Ramsay, Sir Henry Raeburn and Alexander Nasmyth.The house also boasts Scotlands largest collection of Thomas Chippendale furniture.

title: selkirk-firms-help-make-25-000-face-shields
story: TWO Selkirk companies have combined to help make more than , face shields for hospitals and local businesses.Cademuir Engineering and Eadie Bros and Co have worked together since the start of April to supply D-printed visors, of which , have been sent to Selkirk-based workwear distributor Guthrie Group.The Guthrie Groups Selkirk manager Alan Skeldon said: ldquoIts great to have local businesses with the ability to make face shields, allowing us to supply to local healthcare facilities.A club of engineering enthusiasts based in Edinburgh, called Edinburgh Shield Force, contacted Eadie Bros for help making personal protective equipmentfor frontline workers.The engineers needed headbands for the face shields they were distributing to Scottish healthcare workers, including those at the Borders General Hospital.Using Eadie Brosrsquo injection-moulding tool, Cademuir made the headbands using state-of-the art equipment which enables each part to be robotically handled, minimising contamination risk and increasing the production rate to , a day.Cademuir Engineering production manager Marc Phaup said: ldquoIts fantastic to be involved in this important project for our NHS, along with supplying local businesses like Guthrie Group.ldquoThere are a lot of dferent groups who have come together to achieve the goal of getting PPE to our frontline workers.A spokesperson for the Edinburgh Shield Force added: ldquoThis project has only been possible because of the combined experience of our team, the tireless dedication of our volunteers and the flexibility and hard work of our partners Eadie Bros and Co and Cademuir Engineering.Edinburgh Shield Force is relying on a fundraising appeal, which you can access through this link.

title: man-shows-off-160-year-old-copy-borders-newspaper
story: A BORDERS man has come forward with a -year-old copy of a local newspaper.Mitchell Johnston, of Peebles, spotted last weekrsquos articlein the Peeblesshire Newsdocumenting council leader Shona Haslamrsquos surprise discovery while renovating her new house.Mrs Haslam unearthed an edition of the Peebles Newsdated February , , when tidying up the old courthouse at Peebles High Street.But now Mr Johnston, , wishes to showcase one of his own prized possessions ndash a copy of the Peeblesshire Advertiserfrom December , .Mr Johnston, a retired member of the merchant navy, said the paper had originally belonged to his uncle John Somerville, who emigrated to Canada in about  and became the manager of a mill.Mr Johnston said Somerville, born in , died in . Ten years later, following the death of Somervillersquos we, the paper was handed to Mr Johnston.ldquoI suppose itrsquos quite nice to look at it and it reminds me of my uncle coming here for holidays, said Mr Johnston.

title: 100th-staging-agricultural-show-postponed
story: FARMERS will have to wait until next year for the th staging of a Borders agricultural show.Organisers of Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society Show have taken the decision to cancel the  edition.The societys secretary Alison Renwick said the committee "felt duty-bound" to call off the showpiece.She added: ldquoThis yearrsquos show would have been particularly memorable, as committee members had already started working on a number of special projects to commemorate the th staging.ldquoThese plans will, of course, now be carried over to the  event and Irsquom very confident next yearrsquos show will prove every bit as successful as this yearrsquos would have been.Although the first show staged by the Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society took place in September, , the societyrsquos origins stretch back  years prior to that with the formation of the Selkirk Farmer Club .The new societyrsquos formation came after a public meeting was held in the Gordon Arms in May, , to "consider the desirability of forming a society for the purpose of organising an annual show of sheep and cattle".Descendants of farmers present at that inaugural meeting continue to live and work in the Yarrow and Ettrick Valleys, thereby helping to keep alive the traditions and high standards which have become the hallmark of the societyrsquos past  shows.The organisers added: "We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone involved with Yarrow Show, including all volunteers, sponsors, traders, exhibitors and public, whose support is essential to the future of the show."The society looks forward to welcoming you back next year."

title: borders-college-students-deliver-medicine-vulnerable-folk
story: BORDERS College students are delivering medicine to vulnerable peoplersquos homes during lockdown.A total of  students and staff have given up their time to drop off more than  prescriptions across the region.The colleges work placement co-ordinator Verity Hislop said: "The students are quite happy to do it ndash they enjoy it."The college is working with NHS Borders and Scottish Borders Council to run the scheme, which is being led by Ms Hislop.She said: ldquoAlthough wersquove no direct contact with the iniduals wersquore delivering to, we get a wave or a smile or a thank you from a distance."And we certainly know they are appreciative, from the expression on their face."If we didnrsquot deliver, they wouldnrsquot be able to get their medicines.ldquoThese are iniduals who fall into the vulnerable group ndash theyrsquove been told by the NHS they need to isolate.ldquoThere was a huge demand on pharmacies and a lot of iniduals in ious communities fall into the vulnerable category."We sent out a call to staff and students ndash but only those who are PVGscheme members."All the Borders staff fall under that, and also the health and social care students."Originally, pharmacies notied the NHS Borders Transport Hub about prescriptions that needed to be picked up.But now pharmacies are contacting the Borders College delivery team directly with their requests.ldquoThe Transport Hub emailed me with requests for prescription pick-ups from the pharmacy, said Ms Hislop, ldquoand then I would arrange for volunteers to go to the pharmacies, pick up the prescription and deliver them to the people who needed them.ldquoBut now wersquore getting phone calls directly from the pharmacies, with the increase in demand.She added: ldquoBorders College sees its role as supporting our community and during these unprecedented times there is a desire to contribute and add value by volunteering.ldquoThe college is exceptionally proud and grateful to everyone who is involved. This collaborative mission helps to protect vulnerable groups within the community and potentially saves lives.ldquoA huge thank you to all the volunteers, NHS Borders and NHS Transport Hub.

title: gala-rfc-hails-generosity-fans-1-000-goes-foodbank
story: GALASHIELS rugby players have raised more than pound, for the local foodbank ndash and delivered carloads of supplies.Over two successive weekends, Gala RFC invited supporters to drop off food at the gates of Scott Park.Gala president Ian Dalgleish said: ldquoEveryonersquos generosity was fantastic.The weekend of April - saw nearly pound left by players, committee members, supporters and the general public ndash in addition to bags of groceries.The second weekend of collections, on May , raised pound ndash including a bottle of coins totalling pound from residents at Abbotsford Court.Mr Dalgleish said: ldquo[Captain] Euan Dods and [vice captain] Rex Jeffrey and other volunteers were collecting the food and donations at Scott Park, and then the bags were delivered to St Peterrsquos Church for the foodbank.ldquoThe bottle of coins donated by the folk at Abbotsford Court was pound ndash they donrsquot have a lot of money to give out but when they found out there was pound in the bottle they actually topped it up to pound.Galashiels Foodbank co-ordinator John Tucker said: ldquoWe are really thrilled to have all this local support.ldquoNearly pound, was raised in two weekends, and Herculean amounts of food ndash two carloads of food both weekends ndash so our stocks are right up to where we want them to be, which is wonderful.ldquoIn times of hardship people are thinking of each other. The public have really got their support behind this initiative and they just came along with food and money.ldquoBefore COVID, we were giving out maybe  carrier bags of food a week."At [the viruss peak] about two weeks ago we gave out  ndash a fourfold increase in demand.And the foodbank is not the only local charity to benefit from the generosity of the rugby club players.Gala Menrsquos Shed, whose members are making face visors for care workers, was the grateful recipient of a pound donation by the rugby club.Scottish Borders Menrsquos Shed developer Ross Hall described the donation as "fantastic".He said: "It took us over a wee setback in terms of supply, and Gala stepped in at just the right time to help us make more visors."So we had a wee break due to funding and now wersquore back on track. title: aussie-rugby-player-caring-galashiels-lockdown
story: A KIND-HEARTED Australian rugby player has been delivering food to elderly folk in the Borders town he currently calls home.Gala RFC forward Cody Roman, , moved from Wollongong, New South Wales, in October last year.When coronavirus put paid to his plans to explore more of the Borders, he decided to channel his free time into volunteering as a driver with Food Train.He said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate that Irsquom mobile so I want to get out and help those who are less fortunate or in need."For six weeks, Cody has been dropping off food to residents who are self-isolating.He said: ldquoIt got to the end of winter and I was looking forward to seeing some nice summer days, and then this [lockdown] happened.ldquoThe club put a post on social media askingthere were any guys ready to help out with anything, like shopping or dog-walking or anything that people were unable to do now, for people who had to self-isolate.ldquoThe Food Train commented on the post, and I was like, lsquoIrsquoll do itrsquo. And Irsquove being doing it for six weeks now.ldquoItrsquos been really good ndash everyone appreciates it. Some people who live alone might not have seen anyone for a few days, so theyrsquore very happy when we come out to them and have a chat.ldquoSome of them are very excited and grateful. Some of them offer us a cup of tea and we have to let them down easy."Despite being so far from his home Down Under, Cody is coping well with the coronavirus lockdown.ldquoItrsquos not too bad, with Facebook and social media and stuff. title: ex-lauder-footballer-toasts-50th-anniversary-cup-win
story: A REUNION to mark the th anniversary of Lauder Amateur FC clinching the South of Scotland Cup has been cancelled due to coronavirus.Lauder triumphed - over Tweeddale Rovers at Netherdale, Galashiels, on May , .Members of the successful side had been planning to meet up this summer, but COVID- has put paid to the proposal.George Threadgall, , told the Border that he still treasures memories of Lauderrsquos achievement.ldquoIt was like the European Cup for us, said the former defender, adding: ldquoI think half of Lauder was there that night.Led by coaches Jim Brotherston and Alex McDonald, Lauder went down - through an own goal, recalled Mr Threadgall, before roaring back to put their noses in front.After Rovers hoofed a penalty kick over the bar in the dying minutes, Mr Threadgall and team-mates celebrated a famous victory when they arrived home.ldquoYou go to Lauder and mention the South team and locals will bore you to tears about how big a thing it was for the town, said Mr Threadgall, a retired engineer living in Linlithgow.Lauderrsquos goals came courtesy of forwards Jimmy Gillie and Stan Seaton, said Mr Threadgall, with centre-half Kenny Rutherford being the unfortunate player who turned the ball into his own net.The reunion had been planned for late July or early August in Lauderrsquos Golden Bannock pub, said Mr Threadgall.Guests would have included Dave Elrick, now living in South Africa, who was Lauder Cornet in the year he helped his hometown side to the cup.Mr Threadgall, a grandfather, was himself Lauder Cornet in .

title: uk-government-refuses-share-galashiels-virus-results
story: THE UK Government has refused to sendstatistics to the Border relating to coronavirus tests carried out in Galashiels this month.The army ran a temporary testing facilityfor self-isolating key workers and their relatives at the Netherdale car park in the first week of May.But a UK Government spokesperson told this newspaper that the number of people seen at ldquoinidual test sites would not be disclosed.A follow-up request for further details on the Netherdale centre was also turned down this week.Details included whether an extension had been granted.The pop-up facility was one of dozens set up earlier this month as part of the UK Governments push for more testing. The Borders centre was scheduled to run between May  and May .Self-isolating key workers with symptoms were eligible for tests, as were their relatives living under the same roof.These are the questions which the Border posed to the UK Government on May :How many people have visited the Galashiels testing centre so far How many of those have received a positive diagnosis for the virus How do the number of visitors to the site in Galashiels compare to those in other mobile centres established in Scotland How do the number of positive cases confirmed at the Galashiels site compare to other centres in Scotland What further advice treatment is offered to those who test positive at a drive through centre Will the government extend theof time the town has this mobile testing facility beyond May  As the sites are only open to those showing signs of the virus or who are living with someone with symptoms, what is the purpose of these tests

title: furlough-extended-october-questions-answered
story: Chancellor Rishi Sunak has saidthe UK Governmentrsquos furlough scheme willbe extended until the end of October.But what does it all mean for workers and businesses Heres what you need to know.What will happen to workers on furlough Mr Sunak said they will continue to receive  per centof their pay ndash up to pound, a month ndash until the end of October.This extends the original furlough scheme to eight months since it was launched in March.The Chancellor also said there will be the possibility of part-time s for staff from August, pointing out that manufacturers have been asking for staggered shts to reopen production lines.Are there more details on part-time s and can I take a job where The details will be published later this month, but Mr Sunak stressed to MPs that furloughed workers can take jobs where while on the scheme.Government advice says: ldquoIf your contract allows, you may undertake other employment while your current employer has placed you on furlough, and this will not affect the grant that they can claim under the scheme.However, staff cannot work for their employer while furloughed.Will the Government continue covering the cost The Government will fund the furlough scheme, which has supported seven million jobs at a cost of pound billion a month, until the end of July.After that, companies will be expected to make a contribution to the payments, although the amount workers take home will not fall below the  per cent mark.How much will businesses be expected to pay towards furlough The details will be published later this month, the Chancellor said, but it is likely to be judged on a sector-by-sector basis, similar to the details published on Monday by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategyfor companies looking to reopen under new ldquoCovid Secure measures.With certain sectors ing to some normality, others, including restaurants and gyms, remain unlikely to reopen fully for several months.Can we expect to see furlough extended beyond October The Government has said it will continue to monitor the situation and is willing to adjust advice accordingly.But Mr Sunak made clear it is unlikely to be extended.He told the Commons: ldquoWe will keep everything under review but my expectation is by thenthe scheme should end. Wersquove stretched and strained to be as generous as possible to businesses and workers, which is why we have made the decision that wersquove made today.The Chancellor added: ldquoBut hellip this scheme is expensive. Itrsquos the right thing to do. The cost of not acting would have been far higher but itrsquos not something that can continue indefinitely into the future. Eight months of total support is a considerable amount of time.Are there any other signicant changes to the furlough scheme More details will come this month, but MPs raised concerns from self-employed workers who pay themselves via idends, asking whether they would be able to receive further support.However, Mr Sunak insisted current support is strong enough.Why is the Government announcing the extension now Under employment laws, companies must start informing any staff they plan to make redundant within  days of any changes.The previous furlough scheme was due to end by July, meaning consultations would need to begin imminently, but the extension to October will address it.

title: borders-actor-jack-lowden-narrates-bbc-football-documentary
story: BORDERS actor Jack Lowden contributed to a BBC documentary aired across Scotland last night .The former Earlston High School pupil narrated Return to Real Kashmir FCabout a Scottish football managers job in Asia.The BBC Scotland show was a sequel to an earlier programme documenting Davie Robertsons first season in charge.Lowden, , narrated the story of Robertsonsto the disputed Himalayan region.In Robertsons playing career, he racked up more than  appearances for both Aberdeen and Rangers, following up with spells at Leeds United and Montrose.

title: let-borders-garden-centres-open-soon-says-msp
story: BORDERS residents should be allowed to visit garden centres soon, according to a politician.Christine Grahame MSP has asked the Scottish Government to consider re-opening such businesses with safety measures in place.Ms Grahame, of the SNP, highlighted the "physical and mental wellbeing benefits" of gardening.The member for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale addressed Holyroods rural economy and connectivity committee this morning.She said: ldquoAny re-opening of businesses of course needs to be done in a safe manner, giving proper consideration to the safety of both staff and the public."Irsquom optimistic that this may be possible with garden centres soon, given the physical and mental wellbeing benefits gardening can offer for us all in lockdown.ldquoIf yoursquore fortunate enough to have access to a garden it can make a real dference and being able to buy some supplies for it could be a real boost to many. Indeed even a window box can make a dference. While you can currently buy online, it is not as satisfactory.ldquoOur horticultural sector has been hit hard by lockdown, with many businesses losing out on what would be one of their busiest periods of trade in spring and early summer."This not only affects the big well known chains, but smaller local businesses and growers.ldquoI welcome news that this is being given serious consideration and I trust the Scottish Government will authorise re-opening soon."

title: john-lamont-cancels-summer-tour-first-time-14-years
story: A BORDERS politician has announced he is cancelling his summer surgery tour for the first time in more than a decade.John Lamont MP and Rachael Hamilton MSP, both Conservatives, had been due to visit  towns and villages over the summer.But with coronavirus restrictions in place, the pair are scrapping their plans.Mr Lamont, who formerly held Ms Hamiltons Holyrood seat, expressed sadness that he would be missing an annual "highlight" for himself.He said: "Irsquom really disappointed that for the first time in  years, it will not be happening this summer."The member for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk ndash who won his first parliamentary election in  ndash said it is important to follow government advice aimed at limiting the spread of COVID-.He added that he continues to hold surgeries over the phone.Ms Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire in the Scottish Parliament, said she is also "disappointed" about the tour cancellation.She added: "I am very much looking forward to meeting constituents again in hopefully the near future when the restrictions are safely lted."

title: borders-businessman-making-living-unwanted-trees
story: AN ENTREPRENEUR is enjoying success by helping to make houses, animal shavings and food pallets.Douglas Mathison, , of Peeblesshire, fells trees across the south of Scotland through his company Agrorest.ldquoEven with the poorest quality timber, you can still get a lot of use out of it, says Mr Mathison, explaining that unwanted woods on farms and estates have the potential to serve a iety of purposes.Once the timber has been taken to the sawmill, Mr Mathison says, the best of it gets transformed into timber-framed houses, while the scraps might ultimately line a rabbit hutch.When Agrorest was founded in , it served a role that was ldquounique in the south of Scotland, according to Mr Mathison.Established firms often shunned the type of tasks that Agrorest expressed an interest in, he says.ldquoWhen I first started, we were the only one in the south of Scotland that was doing this work on a very small basis, Mr Mathison says.ldquoWersquove been taking on an increasing workload, focusing on smaller jobs that other companies are not interested in working on.Although there are now three or four other firms carrying out a similar role in the region, according to Mr Mathison, Agrorest continues to field enquiries from Kilmarnock to West Linton and beyond.Explaining the typical process, Mr Mathison says an initial phone call will often lead to a site visit, which in turn results in Mr Mathison estimating the potential financialthat could be made on a patch of woodlandfelled.If the farmer wishes to press ahead and Mr Mathison secures a licence from Scottish Forestry, Agrorest will send in the machinery, remove the trees and take the timber to sawmills.The farmer can be paid within a few weeks, according to Mr Mathison, who shares a portion of the money he receives from the mills.Aside from felling, Agrorest carries out replanting and also manages a number of estates.Mr Mathison says his success has overcome a historical perception among certain landowners that woodland is ldquonot worth bothering about.In his experience, he says, an undermanaged patch of trees will be worthy of attention ldquonine times out of .Mr Mathison is a former Peebles High School pupil who went on to study rural business management in Edinburgh.He launched Agrorest after a stint working for a large timber harvesting company.

story: East Lothian Council wants to add two classrooms to the east side of St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School, in Prestonpans, as more housing being built in the town is expected to increase the Prestonpans.ldquoThe proposed work includes alterations to the nursery, increasing its space by expanding into the existing primary one classroom.ldquoAn extension will create space for a new primary one classroom and provide an additional classroom.ldquoOur five-year capital programme has allocated pound.m for the works, which are required to accommodate an increase in nursery provision through the Scottish Governmentrsquos expansion of funded early learning and childcare, as well as the need for additional classroom space.ldquoIn addition, the classroom extension will receive developersrsquo contributions from Blindwells and the nursery expansion will receive funding from the Scottish Government.Plans showing the proposed changes are now with the local authorityrsquos story: The centre is working with Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council on the initiative, with staff at the centre cooking the meals.More than  volunteers at the local resilience group are helping with packing and deliveries.As many as  families are receiving hot meals or food donations, with deliveries made every day. title: grey-squirrels-targeting-dirleton-bowling-clubs-clubhouse
story: Dirleton Bowling Club, which dates back almost  years, is aiming to refurbish its clubhouse because of the troublesome creatures.A new roof would be included in the works, which are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.Improvements to the footpath would also be included but a design and access statement in the planning application highlights that it is squirrels which are the problem.It reads: ldquoThe catalyst for this improvement project is the extensive ongoing damage to the existing clubhouse roof caused by grey squirrels nesting in the roof during the past three winters.ldquoThey penetrate between the pantiles and nest underneath them, gnawing their way through to the clubroom itself.The bowling club has been part of the social fabric of the village for  years, with the clubhouse and steps to the bowling green built in .The design and access statement also spells out what the bowling club means to the village and the potential consequencesthe proposals are not given the go ahead.ldquoIt is the only village sports club providing exercise and social, intergenerational contact through sport, and the only village team representing the Dirleton community, reads the nine-page document.ldquoIf the practical issues set out below mean that the clubhouse becomes unusable, then the club will be unable to compete in the bowling leagues.ldquoThe expectation of visiting teams is now much higher than it used to be, and clubs such as North Berwick, Aberlady, Stenton and Gullane all have new improved facilities.ldquoThe clubhouse is dark and damp and the roof sarking boards are being damaged and holed by grey squirrels.ldquoThere is no lighting to the path, which is also muddy and slippery because water pours onto it from the adjacent derelict hall owned by the council.Now, the bowling club, which has about  members, is keen to see improvements carried out, with funding being sought to cover the cost of the scheme which has still to be calculated.A new metal roof could be put in place, with consideration being given to it blending in to the historic surroundings adjacent to Dirleton Castle.Two windows are proposed for the south side of the building to improve the lighting in the clubhouse, while three semi-mature trees could be removed. The trees, according to the design and access statement, cause a number of issues, including not letting light into the building, while their removal would also prevent damage to its foundations caused by the roots.Access to the clubhouse would also be improved through the resurfacing of a footpath, while a new lamppost would be erected to further improve the lighting.Thank you for reading this story. title: tesco-doubles-number-home-delivery-slots
story: The move comes amid a surge in demand from customers online.Heres the latest information from Tesco, including how to get one.When lockdown was imposed in March, Tesco was only offering , delivery slots to customers.This figure has since increased to one million, with the supermarket aiming to add another , slots over the next two weeks.To meet this figure, Tesco has recruited an additional , new members of staff to pick and prepare the orders, along with , new drivers to deliver them.The extra effort now means that the supermarket has enough delivery slots available to cover the government-provided list of around , people who are clinically vulnerable and donrsquot have a support network to help them get essential supplies.However, Tesco acknowledged that this number is still ldquonot enough for everyone who feels vulnerable at the moment.Tesco is releasing slots for home delivery online when they become available, but demand is still very high, meaning they are filling up quickly.Shoppers who are able to do so are urged to shop in stores or make use of the click and collect service, so that slots can be prioritised for more vulnerable customers.Click and Collect deliveries can be ordered up to three weeks in advance, and slots will be held for two hours. When this time is nearly up, customers will be prompted so they can extend by a further two hoursneeded.Customers who wish to book a home delivery slot can do so by registering online.Priority slots will first be given to customers across the UK who the government has advised are the most vulnerable. These customers will have received an email from Tesco to let them know they have access to priority booking.Priority delivery slots have an eight-hour delivery window from am to pm, or pm to pm.If you are not a vulnerable customer, you can check for available delivery slots on the Tesco website throughout the day, or select the Click and Collect service when you checkout.Tesco has imposed a limit of  items per order online, with some essential items restricted to a certain amount per customer, such as toilet roll and handwashing products.

title: dunbar-high-street-left-one-bank-tsb-closure
story: The High Street bank shut yesterday , leaving the town centre with just one bank, the Bank of Scotland.An announcement was made last year that the opening hours of TSB branches in Haddington, North Berwick and Dunbar would be cut. In November, it was confirmed the Dunbar TSB would close permanently.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who represents the Dunbar and East Linton ward, was frustrated to see the bank close. He said: ldquoMyself and the council chief executive [Monica Patterson] did have a Skype call with Gillian Petty, area director for Edinburgh and Lanarkshire, and Carol Anderson, director for branch banking, and we discussedthere was any opportunity that the bank would change their mind.ldquoThey made the case that the number of people using branches to do their business is very, very limited.Ward colleague Councillor Paul McLennan was sad to see it close.He said: ldquoI worked in the branch years and years ago. Personally, for me it is quite sad to see it go.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, was keen to see the building brought back into use as soon as possible.She said: ldquoIt is very upsetting because it effects the High Street and people lose that convenience of having a bank within walking distance.A spokesperson for TSB said: ldquoWe have not taken the decision to close our Dunbar branch lightly and recognise concerns about the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, which resulted in an even lower level of footfall in the branch and an uplt in customers registering for online and mobile banking.ldquoWe are contacting customers to help them use other banking options, including telephone and digital, and are working with the Post Office, which is less than a mile away, to ensure our customers can continue to access banking services.Thank you for reading this story. title: ambitious-development-offers-housing-key-workers-planned
story: Early plans for land to the rear of the townrsquos Asda store show retail, office and leisure spaces.The proposals, which are now with East Lothian Council, also include  low-carbon affordable homes for rent, which will be aimed at key workers such as NHS staff, police and care workers.The scheme, which is sandwiched between the East Coast Main Line and the A, will go on display to the public on June .Ken Ross, of Hallhill Developments Ltd, the company behind the plans, told the Courier: ldquoWe are delighted to be bringing forward proposals for our low-carbon community, which we are aiming to be an exemplar development, adopting the latest low-carbon technology.ldquoWe will be undertaking extensive engagement on our proposals and look forward to the involvement of the community in shaping our development.The site surrounds The DunBear sculpture, which was unveiled towards the end of last year.The five-metre-tall sculpture was created by renowned Scottish artist Andy Scott, who was also responsible for the Kelpies, near Falkirk.The sculpture pays tribute to Dunbar-born naturalist John Muir, who is credited with playing a key role in the establishment of national parks around the world.According to the developer: ldquoBuilt on the success of the sculpture, the development will assist in creating jobs and delivering housing for key workers, who have played such a vital role during Covid-. It will also play a major role in supporting the economic recovery from the current crisis, in which the construction sector could play a major part.A Proposal of Application Noticeis with the local authorityrsquos planning department for the site.DunBear Park is a .-acre mixed-use development which aims to provide a iety of retail, office, leisure, distribution and residential opportunities, as well as community uses.Included within the site are retail and leisure units, drive-thru units, a hotel, offices, a nursery, care home and elderly amenity flats, as well as industrial and storage units.An innovation centre will also assist in accelerating the business growth of entrepreneurs, business start-ups and SMEs .If approved, DunBear Park will adopt innovative low-carbon technology to generate renewable heat and power on site, ensuring minimal impact on the environment. title: trademark-hairstyle-set-go-boost-charity
story: Ezra Bragg, , known as Ez, is putting his crowning glory in the hands of his we Jen, , tomorrowin aid of his employer ndash the Bethany Christian Trust which has a launched at pound, emergency appeal.She has admitted to ldquonever using cutters before in her le but is ready to do the head shave in the communal garden of their Inveresk Road home, cheered on by neighbours who will be observing social distancing rules from a balcony.Jen, a psychiatric nurse who has worked in the voluntary sector helping those who suffered from mental health issues, trauma and survivors of abuse in care, has set up a JustGiving page for donations.The couple have already smashed their pound target, with about pound raised.She said: ldquoEz has a big heart and wanted to try and do something to help the trust at this time. He was a project worker at the Bethany Christian Centre which aims, through a supported residential community, to assist iniduals in their recovery from an addictive lestyle. title: mekala-osborne-enjoys-outdoors-road-recovery
story: The image was posted on social media by close family friend Davie Martin, on behalf of the family, who described the image as ldquopeaceful.The caption alongside the image read: ldquoYes its our wee warrior Mekala outside in the hospital grounds for the first time in god knows how long.ldquoSo emotional looking at this just trying to imagine what Mekala is just sitting there thinking about. A penny for yer thoughts sweetheart. Your one special lassie.Mum Yvonne said: ldquoI wish I knew what your thoughts are toots. So, so proud of you. Very emotional Mummy tonight.Former Preston Lodge High School pupil Mekala, , was travelling through south-east Asia with a friend last autumn when she phoned home complaining of a sore throat.Over the coming days, and after being given antibiotics and painkillers, her condition worsened and she soon ended up in hospital in an induced coma after being diagnosed with bronchial pneumonia.Mekala, who lives in Wallyford, was then transferred to a hospital in Singapore for further treatment.A fundraising page to allow Yvonne and step-dad Jimmy to be by her bedside attracted donations from across East Lothian and beyond, raising over pound,.Mekala was flown back to the UK in November last year and transferred to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh for further treatment.She was transferred to the Astley Ainslie at the end of March where she is currently receiving rehab.Mekala is said to be doing really well, she is sitting up and had an assisted shower.Speaking to the Courier last month, Jimmy said: ldquoIt is absolutely amazing.ldquoWhen you look at the first photograph back in September of her lying in hospital in Da Nang [Vietnam] and she had a five per cent chance of survival and then look at her now.ldquoShe is still not the same Mekala we know but she is getting there.ldquoShe has got a big smile on her face and we FaceTime every night to keep in touch.ldquoShe is amazing and she can now move a couple of fingers on each hand.It is hoped Mekala will be home for Christmas.Thank you for reading this story. title: hot-meals-delivered-lockdown-due-coronavirus
story: A daily meals service has been launched to help those struggling during the coronavirus crisis.Trained chefs are cooking up meals ranging from shepherdrsquos pie to curries and apple crumble, which are then being delivered throughout the town.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, described the project as ldquowonderful.She said: ldquoI had the idea but I have really only been watching what other communities were doing.ldquoI became aware of an elderly couple who were running out of steam and were not eating properly.ldquoIf, as a community, we have this service available, it might just lt a burden from some families.Mrs Swan noted there were a number of companies who delivered ready meals but many were struggling to cope with the extra demand placed on them due to the coronavirus crisis.Talented chefs from catering company Thomas Franks, who work at Belhaven Hill School, stepped in and have been cooking up a storm using kitchens at the nearby Bleachingfield Centre and Loretto School, Musselburgh.The project also received a generous boost from Mungoswells Mills, near Drem, who donated  kilogrammes of flour.Mrs Swan said: ldquoThe recipients can make a donationthey feel able to do so but it is at cost.A main course and a dessert can be provided throughout the week.Already, the scheme, which has also involved Home-Start East Lothian, has seen more than  meals delivered to households.The project is targeted at those who have been affected by coronavirus restrictions.The meals are delivered in containers so the delicious dishes can be heated, either by microwave or oven.Mrs Swan was pleased to say she had received feedback praising the service and describing it as ldquowonderful.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who represents the title: neighbours-dancing-night-away-show-support
story: Tracey Cunningham, , of Lochbridge Road, came up with the idea after seeing a post on social media of people dancing outside.She suggested to her neighbours that they do something similar, and now it has become a weekly tradition for her and other residents.Tracey, a play assistant at North Berwick Playgroup, said: ldquoI saw that someone had shared something and, bearing in mind that Lochbridge Road is a long street, from the top to the bottom, to get all these people out and dancinghellip I thought why donrsquot we all do it up and down the street.ldquoAny excuse for a dance for me!Tonightis the fourth time Tracey and her neighbours will be out dancing. Each week they perform a dferent type of dance so far they have attempted the Slosh, Macarena and Cha Cha Slide.Tonight the children of Lochbridge Road are picking the song.Tracey said: ldquoTraffic has even stopped for us butthey donrsquot want to we will move out of the way and let them pass.ldquoIrsquom trying to get more people to join in but itrsquos been really good so far.ldquoI thought it would be a bit of lighthearted fun because this is such a bad time just now for everyone.ldquoI know a lot of children are getting quite anxious, as are a lot of adults. A couple of my neighbours have said their children are suffering a wee bit and are wondering how long it will be till they see their friends again.ldquoEvensome of the kids donrsquot know the moves,they are dancing along then thatrsquos the whole point.ldquoWe are aware of social distancing so we are making sure everyone keeps their distance.Her daughter Poppy trains at West Lothian Gymnastics Club and during lockdown has been completing her training through Zoom.Her fellow athletes have also joined in with the dancing every week, pausing their training session to do so.Tracey has gathered a list of other dances that can be completed in the weeks ahead and is letting her neighbours pick the next song.

title: seal-pup-spotters-asked-share-photos
story: Zoologist Donald Malone, a former pupil of Stenton Primary and Dunbar Grammar Schools, will send them to friends at the Sea Mammal Research Unitat the University of St Andrews, who keep databases of seal images and attempt to identy iniduals from them.Mr Malone said: ldquoThis would help gain an idea of the number of both harbour and grey seals around the coast of East Lothian.He added: ldquoThey can also keep a lookout for pups, as harbour seals give birth in June and July and grey seals from September to December. Harbour seal pups shed their whitecoat in the womb before being born and so can be in the water and swim almost straight from birth. Females need to give birth on land though.ldquoGrey seal pups are born with the white lunugo fur and have to stay on land much more until they moult this off around three weeks after giving birth.He saidanyone spots a seal entangled in material such as fishing gear, they should contact British Divers Marine Le Rescuebdmlr.org.uk index.php, which has trained people in East Lothian who will try to capture and free the seal.Mr Malone, who studied zoology at University of Glasgow, has been through this training and has had to aid hundreds of seals all over the world.He was delighted to capture on camera a large group of around  seals, some pregnant, near the Musselburgh lagoons while out for his daily exercise on a cycle from his Edinburgh home.They were hauled out on exposed rocks, just offshore and past the lagoons, heading towards Prestonpans.Mr Malone said: ldquoHarbour seal numbers have actually been in quite drastic decline around Scotland, especially on the east coast, so it was good to see this big group of them.ldquoI am a bit of a fan of seals, having worked on numerous projects on them. title: tims-tales-enormous-turnip
story: THE Enormous Turnip is a well known story about the importance of working together.I have written a rhyming version of this traditional tale, which has its origins in Russian folklore.I have shared it with teachers and parents in East Lothian and beyond, and have also created a film, which you can find on my YouTube channel, in which I recite the story, with the written words displayed on the screen.The idea is that hopefully children will create a drawing, painting of a scene or character from the story, and send it in.A photo of a scene being acted out would work too.Itrsquos up to the children to use their creativity in any way they want.I will then add these images onto a new version of the film, where I will tell the story using the childrenrsquos artwork.After the summer I hope to turn all the artwork into a book, in which all the pictures made by the children will be included, along with the rhyming story.My hope is that it can be creative fun, but also that both book and the film could be a positive legacy of the lockdown with a well-known story bringing together children who use their imagination to create something together for posterity.If you are a parent, grandparent, teacher or look after children please do get in touch about how to get involved in this project, and I can send materials and links.Or alternatively, you could just read the story at bedtimeyou fancy.The Enormous Turnip In RhymeOnce there was a family who lived together in a wee houseAn old man, an old woman, their grandchildren, a dog, a cat, and a timid mouse.The house had a garden, so wonderful and green,Where the old man grew vegetables, the best yoursquove ever seen.One day he decided, to plant a turnip seed.So he went to his shed, to get the things he would need:A rake and a hoe, and his gardening gloves.Then he went to the garden, a place that he loves.Carrots and radishes already grew there,So he planted the turnip seed. Can you guess where In a patch of ground that was sunny and brightAnd sheltered from the frost that comes during the night.He watered the seed with his watering can,Then waited for it to grow, that gardening old man.And grow it did, that turnip seed,Under the ground, at an incredible speed.Soon bigger than an apple it grew,Then the size of a football, then the size of two.The turnip got bigger with each passing day,How much would it grow  Nobody could say.It grew from big into huge, and then enormous it became.Never in history had there been a turnip quite the same.At last it was ready to heaved, he really tried.But the turnip wouldnrsquot budge ldquoItrsquos enormous, he cried.He had never seen such a giant turnip in his le!He couldnrsquot pull it by himself, so he called to his we.ldquoMy dear, my dear, please help meTo pull out this turnip, so we can eat it for tea.ldquoHow can I help  she asked the old man,ldquoWhen I pull the turnip, you pull me, as hard as you can.So she title: p1-deferrals-u-turn-schools-remain-closed-covid-19
story: Several parents had spoken out in anger after their Primary  deferral funding requests were rejected by the council, which last year had the worst record for approving the applications of any Scottish local authority.This year only two of  applications by parents were approved and of the  refused,  parents appealed.Now the council has said all  cases turned down for funding will be granted the money.However they made it clear the decision was because of the current Covid- pandemic and a review of their policy would be carried out at a later date.One mother told how her children were born two years apart but under the current council policy her youngest son would have had to start P this summer while her oldest, who was born in January, was allowed to defer for a year, was in P.She said: ldquoMy youngest was born at the end of December so they are fully two years apart yet I am not being allowed to defer their start at school and they will be only one year apart in education terms.Current legislation allows parents of children who are born in January and February to automatically receive funding for a delay in starting Primary One until they are five years old.Parents of children born between August and December, who would also start school aged four, can also defer their primary one start for a year but the council can refuse to pay for their nursery care.Last year, East Lothian Council approved  per cent of applications ndash the lowest percentage of any local authority in Scotland. This year the figure fell to less than  per cent.The council also refuses to allow children whose parents opt to keep them home and fund the nursery place themselves to remain in school nurseries.Parents who decide to pay for an additional year of nursery themselves to keep their children out for a year face bills of up to pound, and a hunt for alternative child care places.Another mum who was refused funding said she had initially been supported in her view that her child was too immature to start school by her nursery.But they withdrew that support after pressure from the councilrsquos education department, she said.ldquoThey were told that they couldnrsquot support us because we didnrsquot meet the council policy criteria and withdrew their support, she explained.ldquoOur views meant nothing and the impact on our child meant nothing.And other parents expressed fears that their children were being robbed of nursery experience because they have been in lockdown for some of the vital months they would have had and would have no transition into school.One mum said: Children who start school at -years-old already receive a year less nursery time than those who are older, that has been reduced further by the closure of nurseries.ldquoHow can we ask these young children to go from months at home with their family to suddenly starting primary one with no transition A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoconfirmed they have now agreed to approve all deferral requests for the year ahead.They said: ldquoAs a result of the ongoing closure of schools and nurseries, we have been reviewing applications for deferred entry to P, ahead of session  . Due to the current situation, applications for deferred entry and a further funded year have now been approved. Following the full, national implementation of the expansion of early learning and childcare, we will carry out a review of our wider policy on deferred entry.Thank you for reading this story. title: yacht-club-takes-measures-help-stay-afloat
story: The yachts should have been craned into the harbour at the start of April and the committee had an ldquoanxious pre-season discussion to figure out safe ways to continue activities as the coronavirus crisis started to unfold.After the full lockdown, with the boats still on dry land, members have been using Skype on a near weekly basis to plan how to keep the club thriving for the foreseeable and long-term future.Former commodore Mark McClelland has urged members to take part in an online sailing race game called Virtual Regatta.One club member will be asked to take part in a Virtual Regatta e-championship against players from other Scottish clubs and then go on to a UK-wide competition.While playing the game, Fisherrow Yacht Clubparticipants also take part in a virtual Friday Night Bar get-together, enjoying a tipple in their own homes while connected to other participants through Zoom.One of the biggest losses to the club programme is the start-of-the season event called Discover Sailing, formerly known as Push the Boat Out, which was due to take place this Saturday, May .Inez Visser, club spokesperson, said: ldquoIt should have been an open day for non-members to try sailing and to look around the facilities in the club premises.ldquoDiscover Sailing has been the most important means to recruit new members in the last few years.ldquoFYC hopes to be able to recreate something similar later in the summer while taking into account necessary hygiene requirements.She explained: ldquoMany FYC members can sail their dinghies or yachts solo or with family members so, from that aspect, sailing can resume as soon as is permitted.ldquoIn addition,local members can come to the beach already dressed to go out on the water, this would free up space in the changing facilities for those who travel from further away.ldquoCurrently, the biggest challenge is figuring out a way to crew the club safety and race committee power boats without breach of the contamination guidelines.ldquoHowever, many resourceful solutions have been devised to protect people from contamination so FYC is hopeful a solution for watersports can be found soon.She added: ldquoWhile not sailing, the committee has been looking at research information published by the sailing umbrella body, Royal Yachting Association , which has analysed age demographics and water participation in general in the last few years.ldquoUsing the information from RYA, the club is looking forward to how its current activities and club facilities, especially club-owned boats, can be dferently managed to suit the needs of the next generation of sailors.ldquoThis includes not only Generations X, Y and Z, but also third age sailors, as the research highlighted that sailing is well suited to older people because the physical demands are not as great as many other sports.ldquoAt this time, FYC is ever mindful that the club premises are a resource, not only for the sailing club, but for other users such as the Musselburgh Athletics Club runners, Eskmuthe Rowing Club, sea cadets, Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association and the Cooking Club.!In addition, there are one-off story: Alison Blevins, a primary four teacher at the school, posted a welcome back message on social media after the Easter holidays.It read: ldquoWelcome back to the summer term. Please donrsquot feel any pressure to complete work in what are challenging circumstances. Irsquod sooner you went outside and enjoyed the good weather. See you in our virtual classroom ready to be curious, positive, successful and respectful.Attached to the message was a picture of Alison as a superhero, with a cape and buildings drawn around her on the ground in chalk.Two days later she shared a lsquofun Friday challengersquo and asked her pupils to dress up as their favourite superhero.She dressed up as Spiderman and her son took several pictures of her climbing and hanging from ious buildings.Alison, who lives in a bungalow, said her son stood on top of a flat piece of roof to take the images ndash but stressed that she doesnrsquot recommend people try the same at home!Inspiration for the pictures came from an art project she did with her primary four class last year, which saw them lie on the ground, draw around their head, then stand back up and add something to the drawing such as a hat or crazy hair.Then the pupil would lie back down and take a photograph. Other ideas for her pictures came from the social media site Pinterest.Alison said: ldquoItrsquos just a dferent spin on it and Irsquom trying to engage with the pupils as much as possible, really. Itrsquos easy and just a bit of fun.One drawing for an image can take as long as a couple of hours to complete. They are also planned out on a piece of paper to make sure they will fit into the space.While some pictures are based on the topic being looked at that week, others, such as her Spiderman picture, are for entertainment.Alison said: ldquoPeople have responded really well. Itrsquos a dferent way of getting in contact with the children and keeping them engaged in their learning.She hopes to post at least one picture a week.Thank you for reading this story. While I have your attention, I also have an important request to make.In order for us to continue to providetrusted local news, I am asking you to also please purchase a copy of our newspaperyou have notalready.Trusted news has never been so important -and neither has your support.The Courier is not immune to the severe pressures brought on businesses up and down the land by the Covid- lockdown.Soyou are able to buy a copy for yourself - and maybe even for a neighbour too who is not able to get to the shops - then we would be very grateful.Andyou do wish to support us, please check with your local newsagent to seethey can deliver the Courier to you.There is also an E-Edition that can be read on your PC, phone or tablet - just click the lsquoE-Editionrsquo tab under the Couriermasthead on the homepage of this website for more details.We want to be able to continue telling you all about our community heroes: our NHS staff, council staff, teachers, carers, shop owners and shop workers, posties and bus and train driversand the army of volunteers in every town and village helping the vulnerable.But we need your support to do so. If you can, please buy a paper. And keep safe and keep well.Thank you.
