A tea dance with a dference will take place in Derry today. The monthly Mayors tea dances at the Guildhall have been a highlight of their social calendar for many people in recent years. However, as with so many other events, the dances were cancelled because of the coronavirus lockdown restrictions. While it will not be as a good as the real thing, an alternative tea dance will take place tomorrow afternoon. Mayor, Michaela Boyle, and her team are linking up with the Mark Patterson Show on Radio Foyle to create a special live virtual tea dance from pm to pm. googletag.cmd.push The show will feature music from local band Midnight Sun. Derry City and Strabane District Council will be providing a digital archive of some fascinating pieces from the Tower Museums Showbands Exhibition featuring old photos and stories from back in the day. There will be the opportunity to hear from someteadanceregulars, and listeners can phone in to share their stories and memories. Councillor Boyle said she was really looking forward to catching up with some of theteadanceregulars. Theteadancesare one of my favourite events and they have a dedicated following of lively members of the older generation who would put us all to shame with their energy and vitality. googletag.cmd.push This is a very dficult time for everyone – particularly older citizens – many of whom will be shielding at home, and perhaps feeling more isolated from family and friends. I wanted to do something positive to cheer people up by capturing some of the fun and memories from previous events, and reminding them that we will see ato normality and many moreteadancesto come.” BBC Radio Foyle ContentEditor Larry Deeney said they were delighted to be able to reach out through the show. The Mark Patterson programme draws listeners of every generation and when the council mentioned they were hoping to broadcast theteadancewe thought the show would be the perfect . “With social distancing measures in place, now people can enjoy theteadancesafely from their place of residence,he explained. “We hope theteadancehour will help reconnect some of the regularteadancersand allow people to share in some of the special memories from the event. The Northern Ireland Executive today published a phased five-stage coronavirus recovery plan. The document sets out the approach the Executive will take when deciding how to ease coronavirus restrictions in the future. There are no fixed dates for when any single restriction will be lted. The Executive said this is because those decisions in the future will depend on three key things: - the most up-to-date medical and scientic advice- the ability of our health service to cope- the wider impact on our health, society and the economy Among the issues covered in Step  of the plan will be encouragement to those unable to work from home toto work on a phased basis subject to legal requirements and best practice arrangements being in place. googletag.cmd.push Large outdoor-based retail businesses such as garden centres will be allowed to open. Groups of four to six people who do not share a household will be allowed to meet outdoors maintaining social distancing. With the exception of people who are shielding, visits to immediate family will be allowed indoors where social distancing is possible. Also as part of the Step  plans, churches will be allowed to open for private prayer with appropriate social distancing and cleaning of shared contact hard surfaces. title: Ash frontman Tim Wheeler enjoying time with at home with mum
story: IN terms of being stranded anywhere during lockdown, Ash frontman Tim Wheeler agrees that staying with his mother in Downpatrick has to be one of the best outcomes.Unfortunately, this extended period of staying with his mum, Rosalind, who celebrated her th birthday on Sunday, comes at a cost.He is separated from his girlfriend, the stunning French model and art director, Julia Restion Roitfeld, and his friends in New York which he has called home for the past  years.The  year-old is writing music in the same room that he used over  years ago before Ash made it big. Like all of us, hersquos patiently waiting for when thingsto normal and travel is possible again.ldquoI definitely havenrsquot spent more than at couple of weeks at home since  when my father George died, explains Tim. ldquoItrsquos a real shame that I canlsquot really enjoy everything that Co Down has to offer, but at least home is a good spot. Myself and my mother enjoy going out for a walk along the Quoile river every now and then.The third of four children, Tim has an older sister, Heather, and two brothers, Michael and Pat. Their late father was a highly respected lawyer, who became a county court judge.Ash, the band Tim founded in  at the age of  with fellow Down High School students Mark Hamilton, also from Downpatrick, and Rick McMurray, from Killyleagh, exploded on to the Britpop scene in the mid-s. Known as one of the softer alternative rockpop bands, Ash put Downpatrick well and truly on the music map. Along with the success of the Papenfus brothers, Kenneth and Carl, with their band Relish, and local rockers, The Answer, it was a golden age for music for the town and district.Tim and the band have been recording and touring ever since, having recently embarked on a European tour to support their new specially compiled album, Best of Teenage Wildle ndash  years of Ash. Coming in a combination of vinyl, a special  CD with an  rare track CD, Teenage Wildle has charted well so far, coming top in both the UK and Irish Independent Albums chart and th in the UK Album chart.When President Donald Trump closed the US airports in March, it could not have come at a worst time for the band in promotional terms.Tim explained: ldquoWe were in the middle of European tour in February and everything was just gradually grinding to a standstill. At that time, I did thinkI didnrsquot leave for New York soon there was a chance that I wouldnrsquot get back for two to three months.ldquoBut our UK dates were the following week and they still hadnlsquot been cancelled. I felt that I didnrsquot have a choice so we stayed and we spent three days driving to Hamburg to a gig which got cancelled on the day. We travelled back to the UK and then the tour dates got cancelled the day before the first show was meant to have been held. It was too late for me at that point to get back to the US so I came back to Northern Ireland and stayed at my sisterrsquos place for a week before I went to Downpatrick.While he is enjoying his downtime in Downpatrick, rehoning lyrics to songs he first started several years ago, Tim is naturally concerned about when andhe will get back to New York.ldquoIrsquom technically a temporary resident so Irsquom worried about getting back to the US as Irsquom not a citizen or permanent resident. I was planning to move to London in July as we have a recording studio there with a lease ending soon and we need to move equipment out over the next few months. Thatrsquos all a big question mark now. Irsquove been in New York for  years and would like a chance to say goodbye to everyone.Although the change of pace is dferent at home compared to New York, both are close to Timrsquos heart.ldquoThe number one thing about New York that I love are the people. Itrsquos such an amazing mixof cultures. It has so much energy to the place. The pace is really fast, itrsquos endlessly interesting, he said.ldquoBut Irsquove always been comfortable about coming back to Northern Ireland. We are surrounded by woodland and the Quoile river. When the sun shines, therersquos nowhere better in the world. I like going between the two extremes, itrsquos a really good place to be writing, reading and walking around.Tim recently connected with the world of music globally when he broadcast a live performance from his Downpatrick home to raise money for struggling musicians and artists impacted by the coronavirus lockdown. Organised by the Performing Rights Society , which pays royalties to members when their work is performed in whatever , Tim was one of  big names who took part.He started off with a rendition of his hit, Girl From Mars, performed with an acoustic guitar, and played Shining Light, which he won an Ivor Novello award in  for Best Contemporary Pop Song, finishing off with Teenage Kicks by Derry band The Undertones.ldquoThat felt really good and I felt really connected it was good seeing all the comments coming up, said Tim. ldquoBut to be honest, it was nerve-wrecking doing a broadcast from home as the internet is not too good here. Normally on stage you would have fears of your equipment failing but I was just thinking I hope that this internet does not cut out. If the phone rings the home, the internet cuts out. I was praying that no one would ring my mum in the middle of it.ldquoIt just dawned on me while I was singing Shining Light that I had written it in the same room where I was broadcasting from. Irsquove written a lot of good songs in that room.He joked at how long it normally takes him to release new music and how he is still working on songs he wrote several years ago.ldquoThe guys and I have been chatting a lot still and Irsquove been sending them song ideas and discussing things but I really wish we could get into a rehearsal room and jam through the stuff. Maybe we will get to do that in a few weeksrsquo time.ldquoItrsquos going to be interesting to see what new music comes out from artists after the lockdown but Irsquom always on a bit of a lag with new stuff as by the time Irsquove written a new song and wersquore recorded it, itrsquos three years later. The good thing about this time is that itrsquos given me an opportunity to finish a lot of lyrics where I just didnrsquot have time before. Irsquom wrapping up a lot of songs that I started in , so expect our coronavirus album in .Hersquos disappointed, as are local fans, that the bandrsquos planned Belfast gig has had to be postponed until at least the autumn.Best of Teenage Wildle is available now for streaming on ious s and to purchase from Ashrsquos official website store https:store.ash-official .prettyPhoto

title: Ballycran members sewing scrubs for frontline workers
story: SCRUBS made by a group of women from St Josephrsquos GAA Club in Ballycran are now being worn in the Belfast Nightingale Hospital and several local nursing homes and medical centres.The colourful easy wash garments are brightening up NHS nurses and care workers as they look after patients and residents during the coronavirus lockdown.Some lucky frontline staff are wearing Manchester United scrubs or Paws Patrol made from themed duvets.Mrs Marguerite Fowler, sister of club chairperson Shane Gilmore, is co-ordinating the cross-community effort.The core group of sewers are Pamela McGourty, Brenda Coyle, Madeline Bell, Ann Moan, Anne OrsquoBrien, Madeline Branf, Caitlin Savage, Fiona Gilmore and Geraldine McGrattan. However, more sewers are coming on to help out as word spreads about the initiative.The club put out a call for people to help with the sewing and donations of material and were overwhelmed with the response.Mrs Fowler explained that the group came about after she was approached privately by some peopleshe knew anyone who could provide scrubs.ldquoWe started at the beginning of the month and so far we have made scrubs for four nursing homes, including Barrhall Residential Home in Portaferry, and supplied scrubs to Loughview Medical Centre in Kircubbin and Ballywalter Health Centre.ldquoWe have also supplied scrubs to nurses at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast and the Ulster Hospital in Dundonald as well to nurses in the Nightingale Hospital in Belfast City Tower Block through my sister-in-lawrsquos niece who is a nurse. We are now filling orders from Positive Futures, a group who visit people with learning disabilities who vulnerable, in their own homes and had absolutely no protective gear. They find scrubs are so much easier to wash and dry than their own clothes.She said that while the GAA club put the initial call out for help and donations of material, it was very much a community effort.GAA clubs in Portaferry and Ballygalget have also donated duvets sheets and other items, already washed and ready to sew.ldquoWe are also very excited about a delivery of brand new fabric, funded by a grant negotiated by Iain Bell from Kircubbin and District Community Association and we thank him for his generous help.Scrubs provided are free of charge, but the group do like to see photographs of staff wearing them afterwards.Mrs Fowler said the group are able to take requests for specic sizes which might otherwise be dficult to get and they can be contacted via the Ballycran Facebook page..prettyPhoto

title: Community allotment group looking for new volunteers
story: TUCKED away in a corner of the New Model Farm housing estate in Downpatrick is an oasis of calm amidst the turmoil of the coronavirus pandemic.Downpatrick Community Allotments has gone from strength to strength since its launch a number of years ago and there is also a healthy and particularly thriving apiary.With so many people confined to home as part of the the governmentrsquos lockdown directive, the group behind the allotments is keen to recruit new volunteers to help with their upkeep.Those responsible for the allotments are hoping that people will come forward to get involved in and enjoy the many benefits of working on the plots, especially at a time when the focus is very much on looking after your mental health.That the allotments can continue to operate is due to the fact the strict regulations in relation to social distancing are rigorously enforced, with the focus not just on the health of the plants and vegetables being grown, but also of all those tilling the land.Indeed, the community allotments initiative is a success story which continues to blossom and has transformed what was once an area of wasteland into a thriving hub which is also making a positive contribution to the environment and the lives of those who use it.Developed by the Downpatrick Community Collective mdash an umbrella group for a number of community groups across the town mdash the allotments have become a blooming success in more ways than one thanks to the horticulture skills of the volunteers who have learnt new skills and gained confidence as a result.A vibrant and growing community initiative has firmly embedded itself in this part of Downpatrick and continues to flourish, thanks to the hard work and dedication of the volunteers. Only last month, all the hanging baskets produced at the New Model Farm site sold out.Locate at the site are two poly tunnels, flower beds and vegetable patches cocooned into a corner of the housing estate, with the apiary also a big hit with beekeepers who have honed their skills with the help of the Killinchy Beekeepers.Allotment holders and groups using the site regularly produce an array of fresh vegetables, flowers and bedding plants, while the beekeepers are producing their own delicious honey which is in its natural state with no additives.Sean Clarke, who is the chairman of Downpatrick Community Allotments, says there is nothing like working in the great outdoors, filling your lungs with fresh air and clearing your mind.ldquoAll our plots are currently taken but we are looking for new volunteers, he explained.ldquoWhen one of our plots does become available, it is snapped up immediately. Some of the townrsquos residentsrsquo groups have taken plots and we are delighted to have a mix of all abilities working at the site.ldquoThere is great camaraderie and we have our very own gardening guru mdash Stephen Harris.ldquoHe is brilliant to have around the place and has an encyclopaedic knowledge of gardening which is being passed on to the volunteers. Stephen once had his own landscaping business and is more than happy to share is extensive knowledge with us.Downpatrick Community Allotments now has its own Facebook page packed with photos and information about what is happening at the New Model Farm site with the social media page helping generate wide interest in what is going on there.ldquoMany people have come along to learn gardening skills including seed planting, propagation and how to fill hanging baskets and it is clear to see their enthusiasm. It is great to be outdoors and enjoying the benefits of physical exercise and fresh air, Sean continued, revealing that within three days of all the hanging baskets produced going on sale they sold out.Given the focus on greater public health awareness as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, all the equipment at the allotments is sanitised before and after use and social distancing regulations are enforced across the site, both at the allotments, in the poly tunnels and apiary.ldquoEveryone is always two metres apart and due to the size of the allotments, three people can work comfortably at the same time, while adhering to the social distancing guidelines.Sean is a great believer in how working at the Model Farm site is good for mental health and said there are many studies which back up his assertion.ldquoPeople really get a lot out of seeing the flowers and vegetables they plant growing and there is always a great buzz about the place. The allotments can certainly help people destress, especially in the current climate.It was planned to bring along a chef to the allotments so the volunteers can learn ious ways they can cook their fresh vegetables and while this has had to be put on hold, it is something Sean is keen to see happening when the pandemic is brought under control and the current lockdown regulations are relaxed.He added: ldquoWe are hoping that we may be able get a chef in around September, but that will depend on the current restrictions being eased.For further information on Downpatrick Community Allotments pay a visit to the grouprsquos Facebook page..prettyPhoto

title: Council has no plans to lay off current staff
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council has this week insisted that it has no current plans to lay off staff.The confirmation comes after Antrim and Newtownabbey Council confirmed last week that it was planning to make a number of employees redundant, with  jobs affected.However, officials subsequently deferred a decision on  positions, but  agency staff are to be let go due to funding pressures during the coronavirus pandemic.Defending its decision to cut jobs, the council said it had faced an ldquounprecedented financial challenge due to signicantly reduced revenues following the closure of public facilities.It also confirmed there has been ldquono confirmation of any additional funding being provided to councils from government and the UK-wide furlough scheme is not expected to be used by local authorities.While the planned job losses are subject to negotiations with trade unions, Stormont communities minister Deirdre Hargey made it clear that she will not support actions of councilsthey do not respect and protect workersrsquo rights.The minister said that each of Northern Irelandrsquos  councils mdash including Newry, Mourne and Down.ldquoI call on councils and other employers to do all in their power to safeguard jobs so that when the current restrictions are lted, those very workers can contribute to the economic recovery that we will so badly need, she remarked.The Northern Ireland Local Government Associationmdash the umbrella body for the provincersquos  councils mdash said councils were facing ldquoshort and long-term financial pressures like never before.A Newry, Mourne and Down Council spokesman confirmed that no decision has been taken in relation to reducing staff number ldquoat this time.Former NILGA president and Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran has welcomed Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos announcement.ldquoThese are unprecedented times and the local authority has lost a signicant amount of income given the closure of leisure and community facilities across the district, he said.ldquoVarious staff have been redeployed across the organisation and at these terribly dficult times, they are working to maintain services with others playing key roles in helping to deliver food packages to residents across the district.Cllr Curran said he would not want to see anyone losing their job and hopes the local council will continue to work hard to make sure this does happen anywhere within the organisation.ldquoNo one could have predicted the situation we now find ourselves in, he continued. ldquoItrsquos important that the public plays its part, stays at homeit all possible and when out, exercise social distancing to help protect the HNS and save lives.ldquoMany people have lost their jobs through no fault of their own and I hope that in the not too distant future, lockdown measures will start to be eased to help rebuild the local economy and people can get back to work.He added: ldquoThis will not happen overnight, but the more we obey public health advice now, the sooner the lockdown can be eased..prettyPhoto

title: Evan and mum raising dough for charity during virus lockdown
story: A NEWCASTLE woman and her little son have been busy baking tasty treats on social media to help raise money for a local mental health charity since the lockdown began.When Pauline Smyth was forced to close the doors of the Blue Bay Cafe in Dundrum due to the outbreak of the Coronavirus, she and two year-old Evan took to baking some of their favourite recipes.For almost four weeks, the pair have stirred, sted and simmered their way through a mountain of ingredients, making everything from pizza pin wheels to Portuguese custard tarts and posting snap shots of their combined efforts on the Blue Bay Cafe  Bakery Facebook page, along with the recipes.Pauline says Evan loves to help out, especially when it comes to making doughnuts. Together they have raised over pound for Mind Yourself And Your Mate.The mother-of-two says she wanted to give something back to the Newcastle-based charity after receiving much-needed support from them recently.She said: ldquoMYMY are an amazing charity offering counselling and other support services to those in need.ldquoDue to the current Covid- pandemic they are unable to undertake many of their fundraising activities and we would love to help them.Pauline explained when she needed help from the charity, they were an invaluable help to her.She said: ldquoAfter my second baby, May, was born I suffered from post natal depression and they helped me get back to myself again.ldquoIf we could even raise enough money to help someone  in a similar situation get the help and support they need that would be amazing.Pauline is asking followers to share similar pictures on the cafersquos page. She said: ldquoPeople seem to be having a go themselves and are really enjoying our recipes and and having a lot of fun in the process.ldquoAll we ask is that you donate pound to our Just Giving page. Last week we ran a My My raffle for the top prize of afternoon tea for two.To make a donation go https:www.justgiving fundraising bakewithevan. All proceeds are going directly to MYMY to help support their much-needed services..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C May 6%2C 2000
story: DOWNPATRICK ndash Downpatrickrsquos senior police chief has issued an appeal for calm in the wake of a series of serious assaults and attacks in the town.Superintendent Brendan McGuigan has appealed to local people not to react to rumour or innuendo and to ensure common-sense prevails at all times.The police chiefrsquos comments come after a second week of serious assaults which left one local man requiring hospital treatment for sustained severe head injuries, inflicted during a vicious attack at the Bishopsbrae area.Mr McGuigan has also highlighted an incident when a family were forced to flee their Leaside Gardens home in the Flying Horse estate after a malicious blaze.In addition, two other young men were bundled into a car and taken to the Steamboat Quay area at the Quoile River where they were assaulted.Two weeks ago, an ongoing feud between two Downpatrick families was blamed for a shooting incident at the Vianstown Park area in the town and an assault on a woman in Church Street.Mr McGuigan says he is concerned at the number of recent events, which include a local family having to be rehoused in emergency accommodation, and claims they paint a very wrong picture of the county town.The police chief said the sequence of recent events does nothing to enhance Downpatrickrsquos reputation and said people who live in a civilised community must accept the rule oflaw.DUNDRUM ndash A Dundrum man confronted a skinhead burglar in his home during the early hours of Monday morning and forced him to flee the Church Avenue house.The owner was asleep at am when he was disturbed by the intruder whom he chased out of his home.But the burglar, who is described as five foot  inches tall and believed to have been wearing a grey sweatshirt and jeans at the time, made off with the keys of the manrsquos Peugeot car which he stole.The car has still not been traced and detectives investigating the incident have issued an appeal for information.In particular they want to hear from anyone who was in the Church Avenue area during the early hours of Monday morning and witnessed any suspicious activity.Police also want to hear from anyone who knows the whereabouts of the missing Peugeot car.SEAFORDE ndash A Seaforde woman has been appointed to chair Northern Irelandrsquos conservation body.Environmental consultant, Dinah Browne, has been named as the new chairwoman of the Council for Nature Conservation and the Countryside, a powerful advisory body to government.Mrs Browne revealed that as chairwoman she wants to make the council more open and has invited the public to contact the council through its secretariat.ldquoIf people want to contact us with their ideas they can do so by writing to Syril Francey, CCNC secretariat at Hill Street in Belfast.The CCNC is an advisory body which advises the Department on matters affecting the natural beauty of Northern Ireland.Mrs Browne, who has an OBE for her work in the commercial environment sector, said: ldquoThe statutory duty of the council is to look after nature reserves, such as the Quoile Pondage and other areas of natural interest.BALLYHORNAN ndash A recent lucky escape for two stranded jet skiers off Ballyhornan coast has once again drawn attention to the need for safety precautions on local beaches.The pair, who spent more than half an hour in the water without wet suits or lejackets, were only saved by a quick thinking passer-by who raised the alarm and contacted the Coastguard.With incidents like this in mind the Maritime and Coastguard Agency has re-launched lsquoSea Smartrsquo, the campaign aimed at reducing preventable deaths and accidents on coastlines every year.Down area boasts a host of beaches, including Tyrella and Murlough, which are particularly popular with holidaymakers, whilst fishing spots along the Newcastle coastline attract fishermen from far and wide.CASTLEWELLAN ndash This yearrsquos Castlewellan regatta has been hailed as one of the biggest and best yet.Local councillor and Assemblyman, Mr Eamonn OrsquoNeill, was the guest of honour at the annual event and distributed medals to those who took part in the boating races.Students from as far away as Limerick were among those competing in the races which are fast becoming one of the highlights of Castlewellanrsquos social calendar.ldquoNot only is the park a beautul setting for the event, but the Castlewellan Lake in unique as it is the only natural venue in Ireland where there are no crosswinds which would evidently affect the races, said Mr OrsquoNeill.ldquoThe regatta is fast gaining popularity and brings many tourists to the town.TECONNAUGHT ndash A young Teconnaught schoolgirl, who wrote to the Prime Minister on behalf of the Downe Hospital, has received a reply.Twelve year-old Dearbhla OrsquoRourke wrote to Tony Blair appealing for him to intervene and protect acute services at the local hospital.In her letter, Dearbhla told of how much the Downe means to the people of the district and further afield, and explained thatit had not been for the medical attention hospital staff gave her grandfather, who suffers from a heart complaint, he would not be alive today.However, in the short letter Dearbhla received from one of Mr Blairrsquos secretaries, she was told that the Prime Minister ldquowas grateful for her views and that the letter would be passed on to the Northern Ireland Office.It read: ldquoThe Prime Minister has asked me to thank you for your letter. He is grateful to have your views and will take careful note of what you say.BALLYNAHINCH ndash Almost  brave hearts took part in last weekrsquos annual k and fun runs organised by Ballynahinch Lions Club.And each and every one of them was praised by Lions president Bob Bradford for braving atrocious weather conditions to take part in the annual charity fundraiser.The Lions President said all the people who took part were ldquoabsolutely magnicent and their contribution to the charity fund-raising project is very much appreciated.As usual, the event attracted the young and old and  year-old Hugh Turner, from Nottingham, used the Ballynahinch run as a warm-up to Mondayrsquos Belfast Marathon.Another veteran pounding the streets was  year-old James Sweeney, from Darragh Cross, who has taken part in all the runs which have been organised in the town to date.KILLYLEAGH ndash One of Irelandrsquos oldest equestrian events is to be staged this weekend in Killyleagh.Killyleagh Show, which dates back to , is one of the oldest existing shows in Ireland and will kick off at am this Saturday at The Commons off Shanes Road, by kind permission of Mr Oliver Priestly.To celebrate the showrsquos entry into the new Millennium, a special commemorative booklet has been produced.Show president Robert Morrison explained: ldquoWe thought that for a show which has taken place since , it was only fitting that we mark the showrsquos entry into the new millennium in a special way.In what is the first official charting of the showrsquos history, records dating back as far as  were uncovered.Originally, the event featured cows, pigs, sheep, poultry as well as home industries, in what is understood to have been the forerunner to the Royal Ulster Agricultural Societyrsquos Balmoral Show.Nowadays, the show features a range of equestrian competitions and a vintage tractor display. Proceeds of this yearrsquos event will be donated to the Northern Ireland Hospice and Marie Curie Cancer Care.Jenny Adams, the showrsquos joint secretary, says the commemorative booklet is a good account of how the show has evolved over the years.ldquoIt is certainly interesting to see the role it originally played in improving the standard of farming in the Killyleagh, Killinchy, Kilmood and Tullynahill areas..prettyPhoto

title: Goalkeeper Collins selects his all time greatest Down team
story: THE early s saw ato the glory days for Down. The county was a footballing powerhouse once more, landing two All-Ireland titles in the space of three years and the players secured their place in GAA folklore.An immovable force was their goalkeeper Neil Collins. He thwarted Meath in the  and in  memorably saved a penalty from Dublin danger man Charlie Coleman.Now a youthful , Neil began his football career with Ballymartin and then with Drumaness. But he is best known for his association with Carryduff. He broke into the Down senior  in  and remained in the squad for ten years.He remained a dedicated servant of Down long after his playing career ended. He managed the county U- team for three years, was goalkeeping coach of the senior team for six years and also a selector for three years when the team was managed by his All-Ireland-winning colleague, the late and much missed Eamonn Burns.Neil hasnrsquot included himself in his  greatest Down players, but for the others donrsquot look much further than his team-mates from the early Nineties.ldquoThese were the players I grew up with, so I have to stick with them. Irsquom too young to remember the Sixties, he says.ldquoI had a great time with Down. Obviously the highlights were winning the two All-Irelandrsquos, but I have wonderful memories of the people I played with and all the friendships.ldquoThanks to WhatsApp I am in contact with them every day. We had the th reunion of the  team in Dublin last year and we also got together to remember the th anniversary of the Loughinisland tragedy.ldquoThey are a great bunch of lads, but you canrsquot put a foot wrong, otherwise you would be pulled up very quickly. Pat DonnanPat was goalkeeper for the Down minors which won the All-Ireland title in  and was goalkeeper for the senior team for many years. He was a great keeper and became a mentor to me. He took me under his wing and made me a better player. He was also generous with time and advice. A great goalkeeper and an even greater man. Miceal MagillThis is the most dficult pick. It was between Miceal and Brendan McKernan, but I have gone for Miceal, largely because of his performance in the  final which won him the Ulster Bank Man of the Match award. He had a fantastic game and never let Charlie Redmond get away from him. He was always comfortable with the ball and could read a game well. Conor DeeganConor was a tremendous athlete and he could take on the oppositionrsquos biggest players. He always seemed to get on top of his opponents and I never once saw him roasted. He had terric hands and he could read a game as well as anyone. He always encouraged those around him. He was a true team player. Paul HigginsPaul was as hard as nails and he was also the quickest player in the squad, even faster than Mickey Linden. He dominated and bullied his opponents and he had great strength of character. John KellyMy Carryduff clubmate and a ruthless, nasty player in the best possible way. He was the sort of player nobody wanted to mark, whether in a match or in training. He would put his head where others feared to put their feet. Barry BreenAnother double All-Ireland winner. I first played with him at the Red High. Barry always seemed to have time on the ball. He played at a dferent level to everyone . What set him apart though was that he could play with his head up and see what was going on. He was always looking for someone off the ball. DJ KaneOur captain in  and an inspirational leader. DJ was one of the most competitive players I have seen in my le. He would not lie down and did not know what it meant to be beaten. It was win at all costs and he was someone you needed when things got bad. Gregory McCartanA massive character both on and off the pitch. Gregory kept the craic going in the changing room and in the bar afterwards. But he was also a tremendous footballer. He could take a free with either foot. He put money on himself to get the first score in the  final, which he did. Eamonn BurnsAn absolute gentleman, but a warrior on the pitch. He was quiet and unassuming, but had everything you wanted in a player. He scored two sublime points in the , which we won by two points, so he played a huge part in getting us over the line. His death came as a great shock. He is a much missed colleague. Ross CarrA Rolls Royce footballer. He had a wonderful left foot and was one of our two main free takers. Ross had a massive amount of inward drive and challenged us all to perform to the same high standards which he set for himself. Greg Blaney . Quite simply the best player I ever played with. He had it all. He was a brilliant ball player who made the forward line tick. He was always looking to play in James McCartan or Mickey Linden and wasnrsquot worried about scoring himself. An absolute team player. Gary MasonA superb free taker, particularly when under pressure. He never failed us. In June  he played for Down against Monaghan. It was the day after the Loughinisland tragedy. He must have been under enormous mental pressure and anguish, but he put on a massive exhibition and was man of the match. Mickey LindenWhat can you say about Mickey  He was an absolute flying machine and totally dedicated to Down football. He was still playing county football at the age of . A player of exceptional ability and one of the nicest men you could meet off the pitch. Peter WithnellA big, strong one-man wrecking ball. He would hit opponents very hard and early on. Peter brought something dferent to the team and his game fitted in well with the players Down manager Peter McGrath put around him. Many of their scores came about because of him. James McCartanConfident and aggressive with the ability to find space where he had no right to. Every time James got the ball, there was a buzz in the crowd. He was man of the match in the  All-Ireland final. He went on to manage Down and took them to the  final.Substitutes: Brendan McKernan , Aidan Farrell , Liam Austin , Ambrose Rogers Sr , Ciaran McCabe ..prettyPhoto

title: Heather coaching the kids
story: A COMBER soccer coach is keeping local children on the ball mdash despite the coronavirus shutdown.Heather Kerr normally coaches primary school children, but now she is passing on her skills online and on social media.Heather, a player and coach with Comber Ladies and an Irish FA staff member, admits it can be a challenge keeping children active and entertained in the current lockdown, but she believes she has the answers.Heather is also a key member of the IFArsquos Electric Ireland Shooting Stars programme aimed at young girls and she says keeping it fun is the key to keeping kids engaged with their extra-curricular activities.ldquoItrsquos all about making sure that they are having fun while learning something new, she says.ldquoEven though your little ones arenrsquot getting out on the pitch they can still be trying out new skills at home.Heather has been involved in football since an early age and was inspired by her dad, who was a coach.ldquoI started volunteering with the youth section of my local club, Comber Rec when I was , and Irsquove been involved in some sort of coaching ever since, she explained.ldquoI completed a weekrsquos work experience with the Irish FA around this time too and I really got a taste of all the dferent aspects of what is involved in football development.ldquoOver the years I worked through my coaching badges and recently completed my A Licence.ldquoI have been coaching in primary schools for the Irish FA since . I usually deliver approximately  school sessions per week to roughly  pupils in Newry, Mourne and Down.ldquoI play and coach for Comber Rec Ladies. I am proud to have played a key part in bringing womenrsquos football to my home town team and for helping to create opportunities for almost  seniors and  juniors to enjoy the game.Heather says parents can help teach their children with the help of weekly videos which are being released by the IFA and Electric Ireland.ldquoThese videos are fantastic tools for keeping your budding football stars interested in sport and passionate about football, as well as encouraging them to stay active while their usual activity sessions are on hold, she said.The Shooting Stars programme provides opportunities for girls aged - to have fun, make friends and learn the fundamentals of football. Sessions are normally held at  centres across Northern Ireland.Heather says the programme is a starting point for young girls who are encouraged to take the next step and join a local club.ldquoObviously with the current situation the sessions have not been taking place but the coaches have been working hard to ensure that the girls are staying connected, keeping up their skills at home by putting out a iety of social media videos with challenges and tips.The weekly videos can be viewed on IFA social media channels on Tuesday and Fridays..prettyPhoto

title: Lockdown no hindrance to local runners of all abilities
story: A LOT is being said and reported about the absence of sporting activities on foot of the cancellation or postponement of many major events, including Sundayrsquos River Rock Belfast City Marathon, because of the need for social distancing to combat the spread of the Coronavirus.The postponement of the Tokyo Olympics will impact seriously on all the athletes who had been training for the races of their lives this summer, some as the culmination of their careers.But it is not only the elite runners, throwers and jumpers who have had their plans and lives disrupted by the world wide pandemic.It affects everybody who takes exercise in any shape or form, including the runners of all abilities who may not be a member of any athletics club but have been running for years and for whom running has become a way of le.I know that runners often go out on their own to train and in fact many have been resourceful over the past week in finding places which are virtually people free to enable them to complete their training sessions in safe surroundings. I havenrsquot been running for a few years now but I was persuaded to get up off my rear end and try to mark the th anniversary of the postponed London marathon due to be held on the very appropriate th April by running or walking or generally moving over a distance of  or . miles or kilometres.And having sorted out a route around my garden, estimated to be  metres long, I worked out that  laps per mile would be achievable over the five days specied mdash i.e. I could walk  laps to count as . miles. And I also asked my friends for some sponsorship towards the Cure Parkinsonrsquos Trust . I am hugely indebted to everyone who contributed towards this charity, and raised pound. plus pound. Gt Aid. Which reminds me I must go and finish the last eight laps.At the top end of the sport, international marathon runner and Rio Olympian Paul Pollock, while naturally disappointed that the Olympics have been postponed until , feels that it could well prove to be a blessing in disguise in his case at least.He reasons that it will give him an opportunity to concentrate on clocking up stress-free miles in training, enabling him to recover from old injuries and come to the competition, for the first time ever, in the best shape of his le.Portaferry star Ciara Mageean, Irelandrsquos greatest hope of an Olympic track medal since the halcyon days of Sonia OrsquoSullivan, is also disappointed, having been, as she says, in the form of her le, but, like Paul, will continue with her planned training regime and sees it as an opportunity to build up her strength and thus make up the ground on her nearest rivals.Eoghanrsquos viewNewcastlersquos Eoghan Totten, who aspires to taking part in a future Olympic Games as a marathon runner, in a recent interview published in the Athletics NI webpages said: ldquoWhen I recorded a : personal best over the half marathon in Barcelona in mid-February, the virus was relatively undocumented in Europe.ldquoBy mid-March, I understood that I would not be racing for a long time. My biggestfear was that there would be a blanket ban on exercise. Nonetheless, the sanctions under which we are all living have forced me to reconsider the spirit in which I run. I decided that I would follow lockdown protocol as strictly as possible to do my part.Double runshave always been a staple part of my training, allowing me to hit the high mileage required to prepare for the marathon. Completing the same mileage across the week off one daily training session was initially challenging. However, I eventually adapted after two weeks of attrition. In the process, I learned that I benefit from the extra recovery time between runs. This pleasant surprise helped me come to terms with what seems like a more or less empty race calendar in .I can understand that many of you will be disappointed not to be running the Belfast Marathon this weekend, but your chance to do so will come around again in the future. Anyone who is brave enough to step on the start line of a marathon is a special type of person, irrespective of fitness. More so those who run to raise money for a cause. It takes courage to do this. Bank that courage and build on it over the coming months.Athletes are creatures of habit. We are conditioned to race on a monthly or two-monthly basis. Having the options restricted has enabled me to focus on the process of training without looking too far ahead. It has reminded me that, despite thriving off pushing to my limits in races, I love the journey, equally as much.ldquoYes, it is all about achieving in races, but also, to get there a long time is spent training . So we have to love the training too.Right now, I have to wait. We all have to wait. Runners are resilient. Focus on whatever training you can do right now and enjoy the journey.ldquoTo those friends and family in the health service, who have been tackling the virus over the past six weeks, I am amazed beyond words. Thank you for what you are doing.Club updateThese words echo the sentiment of all of us and we commend all key workers who have been put in the front line in the course of their work. We have many EDAC members who are in that position and we send them our best wishes.So what of the last six weeks  The clubrooms were closed with immediate effect and the committee advised all members of the governmental advice to stay home and stay safe. The only good news was that there was no ban on exercising so long as training was done solo or in household groups.It may seem crass to be concerned about the ability to train when there are much bigger issues at stake, but it is well known that sticking to some routine is beneficial in keeping mental health in good order and anything which allows us to be positive will help us to cope with the situation that has evolved.Most have been taking daily exercise as prescribed by the government as it is already a part of our daily routine. However, because of the restrictions on movements and associations and the change of routine for many, whether through being laid off work, working from home, working for NHS at the coal face so to speak, or any of above combined with the added dficulties of home schooling kids of whatever age, it means that many runners are no longer free to go for a run whenever they chose or indeed will have to make signicant changes to their daily routine to fit it in.Some have turned their daily run into a practical outing where they canessential items to those who are shielding. Others have managed to combine their exercise with fund raising for charities involved in the frontline or for organisations who will see their funding hit by the economic fallout of the pandemic.Our juniors could be forgiven for thinking this is an unexpected long summer break, but they report back from time to time to log that fact that they are knuckling down to home schooling while using exercise to take a break.Jarlath and Anna Kearney have committed to a daily .k run, Mackenzie and Ky Murray have been out with their dad, Dee, making sure he doesnrsquot slack. Mackenzie even recorded an unofficial K PB this week.Ollie and Alex Robinson have the good fortune to be able to train as a family and they push each other as well as mum Marguerite. It is no surprise that dedicated athlete Lauren Madine is training away in between exercising the horses. Others such as Emily Burns have opted to cross train.If baking was an Olympic event, there would be a few EDAC records set there too by the sound of things. Tik Tok also seems to be a favourite occupation with some slick dance routines doing the rounds. The one thing that is clear is that our juniors miss their club mates but that physical exercise in any form is a big help. We are proud of our juniors for this mature approach and urge them to continue their efforts.Virtual challengesSome of the races that have been cancelled have then gone ahead in a virtual form, the Titanic K being one. Runners were invited to run a solo K on any course near their home and record the time.Three EDAC runners claimed the reward mdash a T-shirt and medal in the post. Gareth Reilly was the quickest of the trio, posting a -minute time. Hallie Jennings stole a march on Donal Smith by a couple of minutes mdash  minutes to his  mdash but with all runners doing dferent courses it was mainly for fun.Also for fun and the motivation to keep going was the Galbally Runners April Challenge. A simple concept where each runner chose a target of ,, or  miles etc and then had a month to complete. Evidence was submitted by Strava or fitness watch records.Kelly Smith and Donal Smith blew their goals out of the water with totals over  miles each. Marguerite Robinson, Hallie Jennings and Suzy Smith broke  miles in their inidual sessions and Alison Carroll completed a conservative  miles to start a new regime. They all agreed that it was a good way to keep base fitness. Buffs are apparently in the post and thanks are due to Galbally Runners for sorting this.Some runners were racking up the miles and others were thinking of improving speed. Jimmy Sloan has been following a programme which is hard without club members to egg him on, but he has been very successful nonetheless with a new K PB of .. All times are, of course, unofficial as they are not on measured courses but they are a good indicator of form.Jimmy was taking part in the NHS Run , Donate , Nominate . Many of our members will have taken part and the fun can be in nominating friends who would hate to run five km, let alone five miles mdash they canrsquot really refuse when it is for such a good cause!Every club has its mile munchers and in normal times Phillip Vint would see a weekend without a marathon as a waste of a free day. Like others, he has had to get used to a new normal, but when the weekend of the postponed London Marathon came round, he couldnrsquot resist setting off on a . mile course close to home to mark the day.No crowds to cheer him on and no sights of London to entertain him en route, but he was glad that he had the health to complete it. Predictably with the Belfast Marathon also called off, he repeated his endeavours seven days later and clocked another marathon with ease.The best bit is that the finish line is his own back door so no painful walk back to get the car or the train. He was straight to the sofa in seconds and recovery could begin.Donal Smith was to have completed his inaugural marathon at Belfast , as was his daughter, Kelly. Again their hard training seemed lost without a cause, but they had followed the programme to the letter and felt that they needed to test the waters.They set off to give it a rattle and coped well with the dry run of the full marathon distance. They were delighted to get the odd toot and cheer as a substitute for race day atmosphere and they received hearty congratulations when they posted their achievement on social media.While it would have been nice to have friends and family there to greet them at the finish line, it just means that they will have the incentive to do it all again when an official Belfast Marathon can eventually take place. At least they know that they can cope with the mileage and surely with the crowd support it can only be easier Last, but not least, EDAC ultra man himself Keith Reilly has been thinking up ways to raise money and satisfy his need for a challenge at the same time. He decided that his lockdown event would be a treadmill ultra and that he would appeal for funds for NHS Charities Together.He managed . miles running in hourly shts which is no mean feat on a treadmill and logged his th ultra marathon. He was delighted to announce a total of pound, for the frontline workers dealing with Covid- patients. A good dayrsquos work all round.So there you have it from both ends of the scale mdash what the top runners think and do and what the rest of us do. Not a lot of dference really is there  Letrsquos all continue to play by the rules and hope for better times. Stay safe and see you all when the lockdown is lted..prettyPhoto

title: Loughinisland woman ‘was friend to all’
story: THE artist son of a Loughinisland woman who has died has said his mother was his ldquobiggest fan.Sixty-four year-old Mrs Kate Sloan was buried in St Macartanrsquos New Cemetery in Loughinisland on Saturday. She passed away the previous day at the Marie Curie Hospice in Belfast.Mrs Sloanrsquos family were unable to visit her in the hospice due to the Covid- restrictions, but they did their best to support and comfort her remotely by appearing at her bedroom window whenever possible.Mrs Sloan had cancer of the thyroid and while she was unable to eat or speak, her family said it did not stop her ldquopersonality shining through.Her son, Aidan, raffled off one of his original paintings to raise money for the hospice as his way of thanking them for their care of his mother.Describing his mother as ldquoa friend to all, Mr Sloan said: ldquoMy mum was the biggest fan of my art and she spoke about it in every conversation that she could. Even when her voice was taken from her by her illness last August, she still managed to bring up my work in all her written conversations.ldquoEven when she was dealing with her cancer diagnosis, at each meeting, with each new medical professional she met she gave them a business card and told them about my art.She beamed with pride every time I produced a new painting, and no matter how weak and tired she was she still shared every Facebook post of my art.Mr Sloan said that his family would remember his mother someone who would make friends wherever she went.ldquoEveryone who met her could see the beautul, caring and loving person she was mdash from those she cared for as a childminder, teaching assistant, community care worker and a bus escort for children with disabilities, to her friends and family and then those who ended up caring for her.ldquoA good natured and fun-loving person, it was hard not to be attracted to my mumrsquos warmth and passion.ldquoShe had the unique ability to make friends everywhere she went. And although recently her voice was taken from her by the cruel illness she fought so bravely, her kind and loving personality, her fun and spirited nature and her warmth still shone through and touched everyone who grew to know her, even the health care workers over the past  months.Mr Sloan is urging the public to continue to support hospices during as the lockdown.Mrs Sloan is also survived by Paddy, her husband of  years, daughter Roisin, son-in-law Michael, daughter-in-law Dearbhla, grandchildren Ethan, Chloe, Rioghnach, Hannah, Fiadh and Siacutene, sisters Geraldine and Elishand brothers Damien and Des.To support Marie Curie donate online at mariecurie.org.uk emergency or text NURSE to  to help us reach the families who need us. Texts cost pound plus  standard rate message.If you, or someone you know, are affected by a terminal illness, and concerned about coronavirus, call free    to the Marie Curie helpline. You can also find more information at mariecurie.org.uk coronavirus..prettyPhoto

title: Memories of racing at Tyrella in 1980s
story: ONE of the late point-to-point meetings to take place prior to the lockdown was the popular East Down meeting at Tyrella.With fans missing out on any form of horse racing at present, a look back at the East Downrsquos meeting on Saturday, March , , should be of interest to those that love and miss the sport.Acting stewards that day were Major W S Brownlow, Brian McNabb, Brian Fitzsimons and Frank Turley The honorary surgeons were Dr J Erwin, Mr Johnnie Boyd, Dr Welby Henry, Dr F Curran and Dr Jimmy Love.The first race of the day was the confined hunt race with six of the ten entries going to post, and the   winner proving to be the grey mare Lisgarvan, owned by Ballynoe builder John Turley and trained by Jenner Maxwell. The successful jockey was the late and sadly missed George Mernagh.Garryhinch, owned by Mrs Grace Dunlop, of Killinchy, and ridden by Colin McBratney, finished second ahead of James Kellyrsquos Levedece, ridden by R Andrews.Paul McMahony rode Joe Mageersquos Islandmore while Kieran McLoughlin was on Tom Newsamrsquos Charlie Waterloo and Raymond Martin was on Billy McCluskeyrsquos Red Peter.The second race, the Elanco Chase Qualier, went to Celtic Bay, owned, trained and ridden by Ards man Peter Mawhinney, from River Saint, owned, trained and ridden by Frankie Fitzsimons. Ronnie Dukersquos Lucky Gem was third.The third race of the day was the Rearsquos Emporium Open race that saw ten go to post. Victory went to Wilson Dennisonrsquos Let Him Go, ridden by Ivon Keeling, from John McCawleyrsquos Veteran Nightmaster with his son Denis in the saddle.Third past the judge, W H Montgomery, was Adam Turnerrsquos Garland VI, ridden by his son John, whose sister Margaret also rode in the race.She was on board Andy Pandy, which ran in the Grand National and was a long way clear before falling.The fourth race was the Abbey Lodge Hotel Maiden race and it had to be ided. The first ision was won by Harold Kirkrsquos Sir Owen, ridden by Tony Martin, with Fulleria second, ridden by Mike Todd, later the manager of Down Royal racecourse for many years. Vicar General and John Bryson were third.The winner of the second ision was Leonard Phillips Derryvore, ridden by his son, Michael, with Bonnety Bridge second, owned by Sara OrsquoHarersquos mother and ridden by George Mernagh. Third home the David Law-ridden Ballyhock. Harold Kerr now buys horses for Willie Mullins.Only three finished in the East Downshire Open Farmers race, victory going to The Attorney in the colours of Brian Hamilton, providing Jenner Maxwell with a double, John Sleater being the successful rider of this one. Second home was Comber owner Dorothy Murdochrsquos Castlewell, ridden by her husband Alex, with Master of Sands, owned and trained by Dromorersquos George Wilson, third and ridden by Raymond Martin.The final race on the card was the Maginn Bros  and  year old maiden and victory went to Tramps Dream, ridden by Comber electrician Millar OrsquoPrey, who also played cricket for North Down.Ballybentragh, in Wilson Dennisonrsquos silks, took second ahead of Ballygowan owner Vincent Murrayrsquos Mr Deeds, ridden by Paul McMahon. Sadly Millar passed away at an early age.Neville Ring was the noted race reader at the meeting. Advertisers in the race card included the Dunmore Hotel, Killyleagh, which had just been bought by Eric Johnston and Mervyn Boyce of Ballygowan, Daft Eddyrsquos at Sketrick Island, near Killinchy, OrsquoReillyrsquos Bar  Restaurant, Dromara, M J McKay Chemist, Ballynahinch, Downpatrick Farm Equipment Ltd, OrsquoHarersquos, Castlewellan, Ginesirsquos Cafe, Ballynahinch, J  J Rearsquos, Downpatrick, Stewartrsquos Motor Works, Downpatrick, Seaforde Inn, Kane of Comber, Slaney Inn, Raholp, William Laverty Butcher, Downpatrick, and T McGreevy Butcher, Downpatrick. Unlike these days there were no Southern owned or trained runners. In  race cards cost  pence mdash they are now pound or pound.The red and white striped colours worn by the rider of Bonnety Bridge, belonging Mrs J Ferris of Newry, were also by Mark OrsquoHare when he rode Honeysuckle, the unbeaten mare and recent Cheltenham winner, to win her maiden point-to-point. Mark is married to Mrs Ferrisrsquo daughter Sara, whose father, Don, had his only win on Bonnety Bridge at Tyrella..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle family joins the frontline during pandemic
story: A NEWCASTLE father ndash whose entire family of seven work in the NHS ndash has urged people to take care of their mental health during the coronavirus lockdown.Noel McDonald and Ann, his we of  years, are senior healthcare professionals working in mental health services in Belfast.Mr McDonald made the call as he spoke of his pride at the three youngest of his five children becoming mental health nurses during the health emergency.Aaron , Callumand Niamhwere in their final year at university when they were released early into frontline hospitals when the coronavirus pandemic hit.The couplersquos eldest son Daniel, who is , is a senior social worker in the Belfast Trust and another son, -year-old Ryan, works with childrenrsquos services as an agency healthcare support worker.Mr McDonald is an operations manager at the Shannon Clinic at Knockbracken Healthcare Park in Belfast while Mrs McDonald works as a professional nurse lead, also in the Belfast Trust. The couple have  years of experience between them.Mr McDonald is also chairman of Bryansford GAC and his children have all played for the club.He spoke of the importance of keeping physically fit and active to maintain mental health during the lockdown.ldquoAnn and I are immensely proud of all childrenrsquos achievements, especially at this challenging Covid- time, said Mr McDonald.ldquoWe never encouraged them to come into health care. They had to develop the interest themselves. But we are so delighted and so proud that they did follow in our footsteps.Aaron and Callum, were studying in the same class at Queenrsquos University Belfast and are now working at Lagan Valley Hospital, Lisburn, and Belfast City Hospital, respectively. Niamh, who works at Antrimrsquos Holywell Hospital, was studying at the Ulster University at Magee in Derry.Mr McDonald said: ldquoLike any newly qualied health professionals, they were initially worried about going into the frontline but the support and training they got from their universities has been amazing. Their ward manager and other Trust staff have been so supportive and helped them settle into their new roles.ldquoWhile we are immensely proud at the contribution all our children are making at the moment, our message is really about protecting your mental health and working at your own positive self-esteem and keeping up with your physical fitness in order to maintain your mental health. All of our lives have been focused around doing that, including the children.ldquoWorking in mental health can be very draining but Ann and I have so much job satisfaction over the years and enjoyed every minute of it helping people. We wish that for our children as well, said Mr McDonald.He further stressed that help was still available for anyone who was experiencing mental health problems.ldquoWe are very aware that during the lockdown people have not been getting out and about as normal. Those who need mental support could be taking alcohol, drugs or whatever during self-isolation.ldquoThe message that Irsquom trying to put out is for people who are suffering from mental health issues should still be seeking help, even under these circumstances. The health service has not stopped providing mental health services. Itrsquos still open and people should feel that they can access those services..prettyPhoto

title: Orange Order joins Black Institution to help health service
story: THE Orange Orderrsquos Castlewellan District No  has joined forces with the Royal Black District Chapter No  to assist the health service during the coronavirus pandmeic.Last week the Castlewellan District distributed a batch of hand sanitisers to local nurse Julie Ritchie, with the consignment handed over by district treasurer David Scott.The sanitisers will be used by members of the South Eastern Trustrsquos community childrenrsquos and adult nursing disability teams.Members of the Castlewellan District received a share of the Grand Orange Lodge of Irelandrsquos consignment of presonal protection equipment which has been shared across a number of areas.In addition, local Orange Order officials have been able to use their contacts to secure a small quantity of visors which were urgently needed by a local care home.Castlewellan District No  mdash which comprises lodges in Castlewellan, Newcastle, Bryansford, Maghera, Aughlisnafin, Ballywillwill and Dundrum mdash is concentrating its support efforts on locally based health care staff, including those who work in nursing and residential homes..prettyPhoto

title: Pipe laying work starts in Newcastle
story: WORK is underway in the heart of Newcastle on the latest phase of a mains gas pipe-laying scheme.The Recorder revealed last week that Phoenix Natural Gas has seized the opportunity to make the most of the coronavirus lockdown by bringing forward work on the scheme in the resort as part of its poundm investment programme across East Down.Work started last week at the Dundrum Road and Railway Street junctions with Main Street, with contractors switching attention to a stretch of road between the Railway Street junction and Castle Bridge, adjacent to Newcastle library, from this week.Next Monday, it is planned to lay a section of mains pipe between Castle Bridge and the Bryansford Road junction, while seven days later, contractors will be laying pipework along the Bryansford Road, between the Central Promenade and Shimna road junctions.This particular part of the scheme concludes with a pipe being laid between the Bryansford Road and Bryansford Avenue junctions at Shimna Road.Work in the town centre was scheduled to start towards the end of the year, but Phoenix officials have been working with the Department for Infrastructure to identy areas where pipe-laying could be brought forward in order to avoid further disruption to traders, visitors and residents.Phoenix says it understands that Covid- has had a signicant impact socially and economically across the region and hopes that by expediting its works in Newcastle, it can utilise the lockdown period to not only avoid further disruption later in the year, but enable more people to have access to fuel choice before the winter period.The works will involve one lane closure mdash rather than a full road closure mdash with traffic management plans also in place and Phoenix aiming to utilise underground drilling equipment where possible.In addition, the company insists that its work will not impact on Newcastlersquos granite paving which was part of the resortrsquos multi-million pound public realm scheme completed a number of years ago.A Phoenix spokeswoman added: ldquoThe safety of our people and communities is of paramount importance to us and this work has only been scheduled following robust risk assessment and the implementation of additional operational procedures, in line with government guidance.ldquoWe will continue to review the appropriateness of this activity on a daily basis to ensure that it remains the best solution for the local area.Confirmation that Phoenix Gas is carrying out the work in the heart of the resort when it is anticipated that there will be less traffic, has been welcomed by two local politicians, South Down MLA Colin McGrath and Mournes councillor Laura Devlin.Mr McGrath said he appreciates that for many, the ongoing roadworks across East Down ldquohas been a complicated time, but is pleased that the company is now able to carry out additional works in the Newcastle area, much earlier than planned.Cllr Devlin said that while many aspects of le are currently dficult for everyone, it is pleasing that Phoenix is starting work in Newcastle town centre and will ensure that only one lane is closed, with the work not affecting the granite footpaths in the town centre.The schedule of the Newcastle works is available at www.phoenixnaturalgas projects..prettyPhoto

title: Portaferry athlete takes lockdown in her stride
story: CIARA Mageeanrsquos Olympic ambitions may have been put on hold owing to coronavirus, but shersquos taking the lockdown in her stride mdash almost.The  year-old Portaferry runner, who is currently holed up in Manchester, says the current restrictions arenrsquot that far removed from her normal training regime.Even so, she says there are days when she does not want to run and she also misses her family and friends back at home.ldquoWersquore all struggling mdash therersquos days I donrsquot even want to go out and run now, and that the thing I have to do and the thingI always look forward to, she said.ldquoTherersquos days Irsquove cried and been like, lsquoWhat the hell is this rsquo Irsquove chatted to my team-mates about that and you justhave to find little methods ad mechanisms to try and help yourself.Last Thursday, Ciara was one of a number of leading sportsmen and women at the virtual launch of Sport NIrsquos Wellbeing Hub in response to the COVID- challengeThe hub provides instant access to helpful information, guidance and screening that is tailored specically to help care for wellbeing needs.It offers a range of innovative tools and resources, including guided self-assessment via lsquoChatbotrsquo, self-help programmes and digital intervention tools, a searchable five ways to wellbeingrsquo map and a wellbeing information library.Ciara said: ldquoOur mental health is so vital and right now is a challenging time for all of us.A full-time athlete and a member of Team New Balance, Ciara lives in Manchester in the same house with fellow athletes Jip Vastenburg and Adam Craig. Right now shersquos spending a lot more time inside the house than outside.ldquoThankfully my training hasnrsquot changed hugely, but wersquore in the house an awful lot more. The whole season has disappeared, which is very strange because wersquore training without any real focus.ldquoWersquore all watching the news and seeing whatrsquos happening the world over, and wersquore all far away from our families.ldquoLast week Jip lost her grandmother and she couldnrsquot get home for the funeral mdash she had to watch it over Skype.Ciara is worried about members of her own family. Her elder sister, Myra, is a registrar at a hospital in Belfast, her younger sister, Nuala, is a nursing student, younger brother Brendan has volunteered to work in the Nightingale hospital in London and her mother, Catherine, also works in the NHS, while an aunt is a pharmacist. She also misses her boyfriend, who she hasnrsquot seen in a month.Ciara, who won the m bronze medal at the  European Championships and bronze again at the European Indoor Championships last year, happens to be in the form of her le.She improved on her own Irish indoor m record in January and smashed her personal indoor best at m a month later.Training and events were geared towards the Tokyo Games this summer but the Olympics have been pushed back to  because of the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoIrsquom feeling in fantastic shape so itrsquos a little frustrating - we had the whole season planned out, she said.ldquoEven down to the training camps you were going to go on, down to the very day that I was going tointo the Olympic village and then the day that I would possibly leave the Olympic village.ldquoIt is quite tough because all of those plans are all scuppered, itrsquos all up in the air and we donrsquot know when wersquore going to be able to start racing.ldquoThe circuit doesnrsquot have a clue when theyrsquore going to be able to race - it depends on when countries allow more movement and, ultimately, does anybody know ldquoIrsquom not going to feel too sorry for myself because I know therersquos an awful lot of people out there that are in a much harder place than me.In a recent interview with RTE Ciara revealed something about how she is coping with the coronavirus restrictionsQ Whatrsquos the first thing you do in the morning A At the minute when I wake up Irsquove been giving my boyfriend a wee call to say good morning. Irsquom not quite sure when Irsquoll get to see him next as Irsquom in Manchester and he is in Dublin so itrsquos a nice way to start my day and always puts a smile on my face.Q Whatrsquos your favourite exercise A Oh I feel like I should say running, as I am an athlete, butI was to think of my favourite it would probably be a few things. I do miss playing a team sport so probably camogie, I absolutely loved dodge ball in school sothat was an option Irsquod pick that, and I do enjoy my gym workouts getting to lt weights.Q Is there one particular skill you practice every day A Running, every day! Running is a gross motor sport so fine skills arenrsquot really a part of my daily training, but I do work on dferent areas of my fitness every day. I have to work on things such as flexibility and fine muscle control every day to keep myself injury free. In the athlete house though we have been honing dferent skills while on lockdown, trying out dferent Tik Tok dances, press ups, and trying to get our eye in with the sling shot in the back garden!Q Netflix and chill or a nice evening jog A Both, usually we have an evening run, easy four miles... then we chill and watch a movie after dinner. We have had to mix training up a bit with the changes but in an ideal world we get both in.Q Name one book you want to read.A Irsquom making my way through a few Malcolm Gladwell books. I love coming away with new information and enjoy a book that challenges my thought process. Then when I need to flake out Irsquod pick something like A Man Called Ove. Soanyone could recommend books like this to me theyrsquod be on my ldquowant to read list.Q On a scale of  to , how good are your DIY skills A Ohhhh, Irsquom going to give myself an . -  here. My daddy is a joiner so I spent my le watching him make and fix things, and soon learned the names of tools and how to use them. I do know my limits though so I stay away from the plumbing... luckily in Portaferry my dad has a lot of friends who are alsotradesmen so they all help each other out.Q Have you a favourite pre-training meal to help you through a tough session A We usually train in the morning so I tend to eat an OTE DuoBar, the vanilla flavour in my favourite, and a cup of tea. When it come to racing in the evening, something easy to digest is usually what I go for... rice is always a winner.Q Name one movie you want to watch.A , I was planning on watching it in the cinema before the lockdown.Q Whatrsquos the best way to stave off boredom A Oh as a full-time athlete I feel Irsquove been preparing for lockdown for years. My le is basically train, eat, sleep. For me therersquos a few things I enjoy. I love chatting with my family, Irsquom usually on WhatsApp most of the day chatting or messaging and keeping in touch. I also love arts and crafts, Irsquoll be making postcards to post to my boyfriend and siblings to make them laugh, and currently my little cousin is teaching me the guitar via WhatsApp. She is a tough taskmaster, I have a lesson every Thursday and Monday and homework in between so that keeps me busy Q Have you any tips for training at home A Set yourself some goals that you can realistically achieve from home. We are allowed out for our daily exercise so you can get some cardio in outside, find a route that works for you and follow the guidelines. When it comes to working out inside, have fun. Find new alternatives, there are so many exercises we can do with body weight, or with stuff we have about the house so be creative and have a bit of craic. If you need any ideas check out social media, so many people are sharing home workouts. Give yourself a plan or schedule and try to stick to it. Being home means we can fall into the habit of sitting about and it can be hard to feel motivated. At the beginning of each week set out your plan for the week, what day, what time, and what exercise. Write it down and stick it somewhere you can see. Creating a routineduring these strange times means we can take back a little control.Q Name one documentary you want to see.A Anything with David Attenborough, I absolutely love animals and nature, and could listen to his voice all day.Q Have you discovered any new music or podcasts A My music taste is so ied but my wee sis and cousin Tara introduced me to Beoga and I absolutely love it. A lad from my hometown, Ryan McMullan also features in some of their songs, always a nice surprise hearing a weePortaferry accent as Irsquom listening.Q Is there one piece of housework you can no longer avoid A My own room! I actually enjoy housework, everywhere but my own bedroom. Irsquoll clean all day but canrsquot be bothered with my own mess!Q Favourite room of the house to spend time in A We are lucky that the Team NB Manchester athlete house is lovely and has lots of space so my favourite room ies depending in the time of day. In the morning my bedroom gets lovely light, it makes me smile sitting there chilling. Then when I want a bit of company the front room or kitchen is where we chill as a team and have the craic... andthe sun shines, which it does on the odd occasion over here, we have a lovely garden.Both Jip and Adam are enjoying learning how to puck about with my hurl..prettyPhoto

title: Recycling facilities to reopen
story: THE districtrsquos household recycling centres could reopen next week.Located in Downpatrick, Castlewellan and Ballynahinch, the centres closed at the end of March in line with the government directive to help reduce the spread of coronavirus.The Recorder understands that the sites will reopen, provided Newry, Mourne and Down Council can satisfy itself that the move can be managed safely and there is no risk to the public or frontline staff.Mid and East Antrim Council has already opened its recycling centres and Stormont environment minister Edwin Poots recently published guidelines aimed at paving the way for waste centres across the province to reopen.The reopening is expected to be discussed at todayrsquos virtual meeting between senior council officials and the leaders of the main political parties.Members of the local authorityrsquos senior management team are currently evaluating theenvironment ministerrsquos guidelines and developing a staff plan to allow the reopening to proceed in a safe way.In addition, officers are liaising with their recycling contractors, a number of whom have furloughed staff. The contractors are responsible for removing waste from all  council amenity sites, with early suggestions that it could take at least one week to ready themselves for reopening.With strict guidelines in relation to social distancing remaining in place, council officers are looking at the potential risks of reopening the sites and the required measures to mitigate them, with suggestions that ratepayers may have to book a slot to visit.Police and other statutory bodies, including the Department for Infrastructure, along with neighbouring councils, are also being consulted about reopening the sites.Council officers have suggested the recycling sites will open in a ldquophased manner and that certain restrictions will apply.
