Discussions with trade union officials are also planned.This Friday, the Northern Ireland Executive will review the current coronavirus regulations which could pave the way for the reopening of recycling centres not just in the local council area, but across Northern Ireland.Local councillors Willie Clarke and Billy Walker say Newry, Mourne and Down Council is right to carefully assess the guidelines published by Mr Poots and proceed with caution.They say the key importance is the safety of staff and residents, with the councillors suggesting that a visit to a civic amenity site would need to be classed as an ldquoessential journey under the current coronavirus legislation.Cllr Clarke says it is vital that the council approaches the reopening issue with caution, given that ldquocoronavirus is still rampant and people are dying.He continued: ldquoAny decision needs to be based on medical advice and direction from the Assembly.ldquoRecycling centres have not been classed as an essential service and people on their way to such a facility could end up getting stopped by police and issued with an enforcement ticket and sent home.ldquoThe council must ensure that all the Trsquos are crossed and the Irsquos dotted before the centres reopen. I understand there is a need across the community for this to happen, but my appeal to people is be patient for just a little longer.Cllr Clarke added: ldquoA phased approach to reopening the centres has been discussed by the party leaders. There is no point opening the centresthe contractors who remove the waste are not able to do so. A decision also has to be taken on what waste will be accepted at the sites in the short term.ldquoThe last thing we want is everyone landing at the sites, people getting out of their cars talking to one another and maybe not social distancing. People are still dying s a result of the virus and we must keep that in mind.Cllr Walker said that while many people have been cleaning their homes, garages and outhouses during the lockdown, the council needed to ensure that its civic amenity sites can reopen in what he described as a ldquosafe and proper manner.He added: ldquoWe need to manage the reopening process carefully and ensure there are not long queues of people waiting to use the centres, particularly in Downpatrick, Ballynahinch and Castlewellan, with tailbacks of cars spilling on to busy main roads.ldquoThe council does not want to put ratepayers at any risk and, in my view, is rightly proceeding with caution. It is not a simple case of opening the entrance gates and letting everyone in.A Newry, Mourne and Down Council spokesman confirmed that the decision to close the recycling centres is continually being reviewed in-line with government essential travel restrictions.ldquoThe council is currently reviewing this guidance and the implications it will present when it reopens the centres within the district, the spokesman continued.ldquoIf a decision is made to reopen the centres, residents will be informed via updates on the council website, social media channels and through local media outlets..prettyPhoto

title: Ryan bakes tasty treats for heroic postmen
story: SOME superheroes really donrsquot wear capes ndash they deliver the post.To honour the work of the often unseen heroes of the local postal service Ryan Bogues has delivered a hamper of his famous baked treats to the Royal Mailrsquos Downpatrick sorting office.The  year-old, who has Downrsquos Syndrome and lives in Teconnaught, has has to suspend his popular Ryanrsquos Cookie Box initiative, which he started over four years ago, because of the coronavirus lockdown.Ryan was praised by Prime Minister Boris Johnston last year for fundraising for several charities through his Cookie Box scheme where people donate money for his baked goods.Hersquos helped by his mother, Hazel, who explained a line in a recent speech from Taoiseach Leo Varadkar inspired them to think of local postal workers.ldquoMr Varadkar used the line lsquonot all superheroes wear capesrsquo and that struck a chord with us, she said.ldquoWe have had to close the Cookie box, but Ryan wanted to still help. We have an excellent postwoman and thought that the postal workers were among the very many key workers who were all working really hard to ensure that their service goes on as normal so we felt that they deserved a Ryanrsquos Cookie Box hamper.She added that Ryan bakes enough goods to donate two hampers per week since the lockdown and they have gone to nursing homes, pharmacists and hospitals as well.The hamper, which contained a range of buns, traybakes and lemon drizzle cake was well received by the  men and women who work at the sorting office at the Ballydugan Road Industrial Estate.Manager Donal Carabine received the hamper last week and said it helped lt everyonersquos spirits.ldquoEveryone at the delivery office has been working hard to both work in new ways to ensure everyonersquos safety at work while continuing with our service, said Mr Carabine.ldquoWe are delighted to have been recognised as being amongst key workers by Ryan and his mother and the baked goods are appreciated by all. We thank them for their generosity and I can assure them that the treats didnrsquot last too long.Mr Carabine said that the staff were coping with delivering items, mainly packages, and were as busy as they would be at Christmas mdash the busiest time of the year.ldquoI think the staff are coping admirably with the demand, as well as abiding by the two-metre social distancing rule in work. We have had to reorganise the office and stagger the earlier start times of some staff but they have all risen to the challenge.The Downpatrick office delivers throughout the wider Downpatrick area as far as Seaforde, Ardglass, Crossgar and Saintfield.Mr Carabine said: ldquoThe workers are more than holding their own in terms of maintaining deliveries and keeping themselves safe, although in some areas, due to the need to protect workers, the service is a bit later than usual..prettyPhoto

title: Saintfield’s Leah battling to raise cash for charity
story: A SAINTFIELD mum is throwing her weight behind a gruelling event to raise money for charity.Leah McCourt, a champion mixed martial arts fighter, is undergoing a test of strength and endurance challenge for Christian Aid, which is responding to the coronavirus crisis in some of the poorest countries in the world.Over five days, -year-old Leah will be attempt to complete , exercises carrying a weighted bag used by combat athletes to build strength.Starting on Monday, Leah will complete the daunting daily task of , squats and lunges while carrying on her shoulders the crescent-shaped lsquoBulgarian bagrsquo filled with  kilos of sand and wool. Each daily session is likely to take up to three hours to complete.Leah is a professional MMA fighter and earlier this year she headlined a prestigious event in DublinHer fundraiser is in response to Christian Aidrsquos appeal to people to raise money by taking part in sponsored stay-at-home challenges as part of Christian Aid Week which runs from May -.Examples include completing , star jumps in the living room, a half marathon in the back garden, or the equivalent of a mountain climb by walking up and down the stairs.Leah is urging others to follow her example. ldquoThe current crisis has left many people feeling helpless, she said.ldquoHowever, it is still possible to do something positive and help others during the lockdown.ldquoExercise is important for our physical and mental health, but it also lts your spirits knowing you are raising funds to support a good cause.As the pandemic passes its peak in the developed world, the aid agency hopes that Leahrsquos endorsement will raise funds vital to slowing the spread of the virus in developing countries where there are few,any, ventilators and ICU beds.Christian Aid Ireland Chief Executive Rosamond Bennett thanked Leah for her support.ldquoLeah is a true champion and I hope she inspires others to take up the challenge, she said.ldquoChristian Aid works in some of the poorest countries in the world, and coronavirus cases have been reported in every one of them. We know the impact the virus has had here but poor countries donrsquot have enough doctors and nurses and very few,any ventilators or ICU beds.ldquoPeople wonrsquot get the treatment they needthey do fall ill, so itrsquos vital we do all we can to help make sure people protect themselves from coronavirus and help prevent the spread of the disease.In order to carry out its work, the charity relies heavily on the donations it receives each during Christian Aid Week.The majority of these donations come from door-to-door and annual church service collections, neither of which is possible because of current restrictions.Christian Aid tackles the root causes of poverty around the world and is currently responding to the coronavirus crisis in nearly  countries by helping to raise awareness of the importance of regular hand washing and physical distancing to prevent the spread of the disease, as well as distributing soap and improving access to water.To support Leahrsquos sponsored stay-at-home challenge, visit her Justgiving page at https:www.justgiving fundraising christianaid-leah-mccourt.To sign up for Christian Aidrsquos Active Aid campaign, visit www.caid.ie activeaid..prettyPhoto

title: Sisters caring for abandoned lambs
story: A SMALL flock of orphaned lambs have found a new home thanks to three sisters from Clough.The pet lambs, which are less than a month old, were abandoned by their mothers, but are now in the loving care of the Ashe sisters mdash  year-old Charlotte, eight year-old Ruby and Eliza, who is six.The lambs, named Lucky, Spud, Tommy, Shaun, Buttercup and Maggie, are too young to be put out to pasture and are being bottle-fed four times a day.Their new home is a field off the Claragh Road, they have comfy straw beds to sleep on and their new playmates are three young girls who canrsquot believe their luck.The girls are currently off school because of the lockdown and looking after the lambs is a fantastic way to spend their time between when theyrsquore not doing homework and helping with chores at home.Their mum, Cara, said: ldquoThe girls are loving every minute of it. At the moment theyrsquore basically living their lives around the lambs.ldquoAs soon as they wake up they go up to the field and give the lambs their first bottles of the day. Then they go home, have their own breakfast and do some homework. Around am they go back to see the lambs. After that itrsquos lunch, more homework and dinnertime for the lambs.ldquoThe girls keep the lambs in a field beside their grandad Erniersquos house. They play in the field most of the day and are kept in a secure pen at night.Each lamb has its own personality and they start bleating when they hear the girlsrsquo voices. They canrsquot wait to get to them.The girls are also learning quickly about what is required to keep livestock. They have a log book in which they record their weight and how much they eat.Adds Cara: ldquoCharlotte would like to become a vet and this is a great experience for her. In fact, all the girls are learning a lot and they would like to thank farmers who gave the lambs for providing them with this experience..prettyPhoto

title: There’s great work being done by the Irish in New York
story: A FORMER Ardglass man now living in New York has revealed how the Irish community have been coming together to support each other during the Covid- pandemic.Tommy McConvey was hoping to travel back home to celebrate his th birthday among his family and neighbours in Curranrsquos Bar in Chapeltown later this month. He is disappointed at having to postpone his trip, but says itrsquos better to remain in New York.Tommy, who is a treasurer of a global finance company, usually commutes by subway into the heart of the Big Apple each day. However, since the city went into lockdown on March , Tommy has been self-isolating at home with his girlfriend, Lia.The former Crew Road resident has been living in New York since ,after he completed his Masters degree at Queenrsquos University Belfast, and says he only intended staying for six weeks.That same year he flew to Dublin on September  mdash the same day as the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, which he and friends had visited the previous day.ldquoWe had taken pictures with the security guards and other workers and it still haunts me wonderingthose guys were able to make it out alive, he says.Tommy says that  years on fear has ed to the streets of New York.ldquoAt the beginning of the pandemic back in early March our company was swt to respond. We put social distancing measures in place and rotated staff on a sht basis so that only a third of workers were in the office each day.ldquoWe knew the virus was going to get more severe so after we learned the St Patrickrsquos Day parade was to be cancelled we took that as a signal and mandated that all staff should stay at home.Tommy says the sweeping changes have left an eerie feeling in their wake.ldquoIn the first few weeks the only workers that remained in the city centre were builders availing of free movement and the empty streets to get ahead with development projects, but they too were forced to quit, he said.ldquoTraffic has all but ceased, apart from a few ambulances and delivery trucks.ldquoThe economic impact of coronavirus has been devastating, particularly for the Irish who have found themselves furloughed off, out of work and not entitled to any government aid.ldquoA charity has been set up called Slainte  which was formed with the sole intention of alleviating the suffering that many have been going through and to help those less fortunate to get through it.Tommy is also a leading figure in the GAA in New York which is supporting Slainte .At the weekend local Gaelic footballers in the city ran a combined distance of , kilometres, which is the equivalent of running theof Ireland, from Malin Head in Donegal to Mizzen Head in Cork mdash and back.The event was in place of a cancelled Gaelic football tournament and all proceeds went to Slainte .ldquoOver half of the people who have applied for help from Slainte  are in the hospitality industry which looks to be one of the last groups that willto work in all likelihood.ldquoThere is also a lot of great work being done by other Irish community groups in New York.Tommy says it is very encouraging to see the Irish community pull together during a time like this.He said: ldquoThe Irish are renowned for putting their shoulder to the wheel in times of adversity and the last few weeks have been no dferent.ldquoWersquore looking after each other as we always have done when hardship strikes.Tommy says people can still make donations to Slainte  by going to the link www.slainte.org..prettyPhoto

title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. title: we need proper public debate about whether harm covid  justifies cost lockdown and closing down entire economy
story: Ballycastle tragedy: Mum Clare and daughter Bethany attended Bush Tots group - Presbyterian Church urges people to pray for other daughter Hannah still in hospitalDevastation after mother and young daughter killed in collision between quad and tractor near their homeNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsOpinionWe need a proper public debate about whether the harm of Covid- justies the cost of lockdown and closing down an entire economyTruth be told, I am quite enjoying the current lockdown, but then I mostly work from home anyway.By James DingleyWednesday, th May , : pmUpdated Wednesday, th May , : pm""There is public appreciation on a Thursday evening for NHS workers but when the emergency is over how many will vote for higher taxes to fund better services  : GuzelianBut what I really appreciate is how calm and peaceful it is outside, especially with the sun shining, almost no traffic and few people on the streets. That said, I am also lucky in having a very nice home, with a good garden in a leafy suburb and a steady work pension. However, spare a thought for those not so lucky and with no garden or nice leafy suburb, also those not feeling secure in ing to a job or restarting a business once we are unlocked.Dr James Dingley is a Belfast based academic and chair of the Francis Hutcheson Institute : Other rd Party " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This latter is an increasingly serious point since there is a growing tendency to see unlocking in terms of an economy versus health choice. The two are irretrievably entwined.First, lost jobs and businesses do cost lives, not dramatically in a sudden endemic. It kills just as surely over a period of time and also eats up expensive health, social and welfare services that we may need to help fend off the next pandemic. Second, the economy is what pays for our health, social and welfare services. Poor economy means fewer resources both in terms of increased demand for those services whilst concurrently implying a lower tax yield and hence lower income stream for those services we are now so appreciative of. Of course it must be gratying for those concerned to see all the public appreciation, on a Thursday evening, for their services. However, I cannot help wondering just how long this will last after the emergency is over. How many will vote for higher taxes to pay for better services, especially social welfare which takes such a burden off the NHS  How many tax dodgers in off-shore funds will volunteer to repatriate their billions to pay tax on it to maintain the NHS  What effort by our politicians and civil servants to clean up their act and ensure no more RHI scandals so that the money saved can go into better care and health facilities. Fewer £,pa Spads and more nurses or bio-medical scientists might be a good start, then we would also need fewer multi-million pound inquiries. Quiz our politicians, now that they are back, on that one.Meanwhile, we still have to deal with the current pandemic, and here I wish to raise a, not unrelated, serious question: just how serious is the current pandemic  I am not trying to trivialise, but deaths happen all the time, it’s normal.Thus the question arises of: how big an increase in deaths over the normal rate is currently occurring  Here one has to turn to the statistics, which are always dficult to analyse adequately, hence imperfect, but all that the decision takers have to go on.Working from the Office of National Statistics for England and Wales, week ending th March,  : .%deaths in the over  bracket involved Covid-: in - bracket it was .% : meanwhile no Covid- deaths were recorded in the under one and - age groups. Meanwhile, the total number of Covid- deaths was , out of a total of , deaths , thus  Covid- deathswere in the age group +. Meanwhile, .% of all deaths mentioned ‘influenza or pneumonia’ , Covid- or both. By comparison, the previous five year average for deaths involving influenza and pneumonia was .%.The foregoing is just an example of the kind of figures decision makers will have to grapple with. First this seems to be a virus that particularly affects the elderly and those with underlying respiratory conditions. When placing Covid- related deaths in perspective, the majority appear to affect those who have already reached, or nearly, the modern average le expectancy . More recent data since that cited above confirms that the median age of people who die is over .Is it just that a new disease is carrying us off rather than an old one If that is the case, then what is the justication for closing down an entire economy, which will also involve many premature deaths, perhaps of much younger and potentially more productive people.This is not an easy or comfortable question, and I am not proposing any answer, but it is one that needs asking and should be the basis for proper public debate, both in the media and politically.As the News Letter editorial ‘The world’s oldest daily newspaper is reporting this pandemic as it has reported other global health crises over the centuries,’ April  reminds us, in  , died from plague in Constantinople – that would cause panic, but we should not. Covid- is serious, but just how much in the great scheme of things has yet to be fully appraised and we need to keep calm and, especially, think rationally of how and where we limit the worst effects.• Dr James Dingley is chairman of Francis Hutcheson Institute

title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls keir starmers labour leadership win ray hope difficult times
story: The MP for Holborn and St Pancras defeated Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir, who won on the first round of voting with . per cent of ballots cast.Stephen called Sir Keirs ascension a ray of hope, and said that the party should now turn its attention to winning elections.He said: ldquoI am so pleased that Keir Starmer has become UK Labour leader.ldquoThe ray of hope Keir represents could not come at a more critical time.ldquoHis message of unity has won over members up and down the country ndash and we need to ensure that we model that through the whole of the UK Labour Party.ldquoAnd it is clear that Labour comes out of this contest stronger, with Rebecca and Lisa running really positive campaigns.ldquoThe UK General Election result in December was devastating for Labour and we cannot repeat it."Thatrsquos why Keirrsquos campaign was all about focussing the party on winning elections. Only then can we change peoplersquos lives."Welsh Labour, and First Minister Mark Drakeford will now be working closely with Keir to ensure we win the Senedd elections next year.ldquoKeir has already shown his commitment to Wales and Welsh Labour, and personally visited Cardf South and Penarth with me just a few months ago to meet local residents.ldquoWe also need to restore peoplersquos trust in the Labour Party as a force for good - a crucial part of that is tackling antisemitism."I know that Keir has the values, vision and moral compass needed to fight for justice at home and abroad ndash and that is needed more than ever.ldquoNobody could have predicted the campaign ending in these hugely dficult circumstances - and regardless of the result, our primary thoughts at the moment are with all those affected by coronavirus, and our brilliant NHS and social care staff, and key workers up and down the country who are keeping us going and saving lives every day."The Labour Partyrsquos number one priority right now is working across party lines to help the country get through this.ldquoI am also delighted Angela Rayner has been elected our new UK Deputy Leader ndash someone who I have campaigned with on a range of issues over many years. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: virus decimated marie curie hospice charity income penarth
story: End of le patients who do not want to be in hospital need to be moved to a more appropriate setting, as beds in critical care units are urgently required for patients who need lesaving treatment.The charity, which relies upon public donations and fundraising events needs to raise pound million a year to continue to run its essential frontline services across Wales.However, chief executive Matthew Reed has said the charityrsquos income has been lsquodecimatedrsquo due to the outbreak.Rachel Moses-Lloyd from Marie Curie in Wales said: ldquoWhen the NHS and public need us most, we are facing huge dficulties raising our vital funds."Along with the cancellation of hundreds of high street and supermarket collections, wersquore now losing income from the closure of our charity shops and from cancelled fundraising events."The Marie Curie Cardf and the Vale Hospice in Penarth cares for around , people each year.Its manager, Sarah Lloyd-Davies, said: ldquoAcross Marie Curie we have provided care to a few terminally ill patients who have tested positive for coronavirus or are suspected of having it and do expect this to continue in future. For reasons of patient confidentiality we are not able to discuss specic cases of care from the hospice or from the community nursing care we provide.ldquoOur hospice staff and nursing teams across Cardf and the Vale are very much on the frontline and have an important job in keeping patients out of hospital to relieve pressure on the NHS. That is important now more than ever given the coronavirus crisis. The health and wellbeing of our patients, their loved ones, and our staff is our top priority and across the hospice and community we are taking steps to protect them. This includes the use of PPE and, in-line with other providers of care, including the NHS, we have amended our visiting rules at the hospice.ldquoWith regards PPE, unfortunately, our hospice and community nursing service have been facing the same issues as the NHS in terms of getting all the equipment they need. We are screening patients with a phone call before attending their homes and staff will wear the appropriate PPE equipment during every household visit. However, we can only do this when we have the right PPE equipment available and are grateful to have recently received support from our colleagues at the Cardf and the Vale University Health Board to gain access to some PPE through their supply, for which we give our thanks.ldquoHowever we are always in need of more supplies to continue to provide vital end of le care to people living with a terminal illness, especially at this dficult time. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls international cooperation tackle coronavirus new labour frontbench role
story: The MP for Cardf South and Penarth will work alongside the Shadow Foreign Secretary, Lisa Nandy, as a joint Shadow Foreign Office and International Development Minister for the African continent.He was previously appointed as Shadow Minister for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs until he resigned from the position in .During his live daily Q and A session yesterday, Mr Doughty said: "I got a call from the Sir Kier Starmer yesterday letting me know hed like me to be a Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Development."Ill be working in two dferent teams with Lisa Nandy and Preet Kaur Gill - both fantastic people and Im delighted to be working with them."And the full front bench team was announced today so it will be a delight to go back and be in a shadow ministerial role."Its something that I feel Ive got a lot to contribute on but also is going to be so crucial because were seeing the impacts that coronavirus is having in this country with a developed health system with relatively strong levels of support for people, though I appreciate at the moment its incredibly dficult for people but compared to some countries around the world who literally dont have any of the type of equipment or expertise or staffing that we do in our health service."Im really fearful of some of the impact that will have in some of the poorest countries around the world, so this is undoubtedly going to be a big issue over the next few months and Im going to be working very closely with Kiers team to make sure we get the right support from governments across the world working together because were not going to solve this crisis by putting up barriers."Sir Keir won the Labour leadership contest in the first round of voting at a ballot last week, where he competed against Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir and called his victory a ray of hope. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Wersquove got the capacity to do it.Matthew went on to describe the atmosphere at Llandough Hospital.ldquoWersquore both in Penarth and wersquove lived here all our lives. Its important to us that we support it as much as possible.ldquoIts uplting being able to do that. title: strategy announced lead wales lockdown
story: The framework will help to determine when the strict stay-at-home restrictions can begin to be relaxed in Wales and will help to find a way for people in Wales to live and work alongside coronavirus.A Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing is being developed through the office of the Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton. This will highlight the importance of community testing and support the containment of emerging coronavirus infections as and when restrictions are eased.Launching the framework, the First Minister said: ldquoOur approach to date has been one of lockdown. We have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.ldquoThis has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and, even though we have sadly seen more than  people die, it has helped to save many more lives. But this strategy comes with its own costs to peoplersquos wider health and wellbeing and long-term costs to our economy.ldquoWe are keeping these regulations under constant review. We know coronavirus will be with us for a long time yet but we want to see whether there are things we can do while we continue to tackle the virus and while the search for better treatments and a vaccine continue.The framework ndash and the seven questions ndash will help determine when the time is right to relax some of the stay-at home regulations.The seven questions are:bull Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus bull Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection bull How can it be monitored and enforced bull Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences bull Does it have a positive economic benefit bull Does it have a positive impact on peoplersquos wellbeing bull Does it have a positive impact on equality The Chief Medical Officer for Walesrsquo office has developed the Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing.It will have four main strands ndash improved surveillance of cases of coronavirus effective identication of cases and contact tracing learning from international experience and engaging with the public.Dr Atherton said: ldquoAction to ease the lockdown restrictions will need to be supported by a comprehensive public health response, which will need to developed quickly and at scale.ldquoAcross the UK, we have worked and put in place unprecedented measures to contain and delay the spread of coronavirus. We have also worked to reduce the overall impact of the virus by strengthening essential services, including healthcare.ldquoWe are now working towards a new recovery phase to lead us out of the pandemic but only when the conditions are right.The First Minister added: ldquoCoronavirus is not going to disappear ndash it is likely it will be with us for a long time. We will need to have some sort of restrictions in place for some time yet to continue to control the spread of the virus and reduce community transmission. This framework will help us determine what is right for Wales.ldquoThere is a long road ahead of us towards recovery to pre-pandemic levels, butwe continue to work together, I hope we will be able to make changes to the restrictions and see a gradualto something resembling normal le.The Welsh Government has worked closely with the rest of the UK throughout the pandemic and has shared the development of the framework with the Scottish, Northern Irish and the UK governments. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... earlier this week following a review by the Penarth Town Council.The council previously closed the cemetery to visitors in March to tackle the spread of the coronavirus.The cemetery will be be open who remain dear to them.ldquoTo ensure that this can continue, we ask all visitors to take good care of themselves and others by observing current health guidance, including social distancing.ldquoWe must also ask that the grounds are not used for exercise or dog walking.ldquoPlease help us look after the cemetery by taking any waste materials home.ldquoPlease note that the toilets remain closed.ldquoFor health and safety reasons, it will be necessary for us to close the grounds during a funeral.ldquoIn current circumstances grounds maintenance has been scaled back and normal ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsCoronavirus: Shoppers told to think of others more needy than themselves when ordering grocery deliveriesConsumers are being urged to think of others before themselves when shopping online, amid an “unprecedented” swell in demand for food deliveries.By Adam KulaMonday, th May , : pm""Image showing a -minute wait today before shoppers can even see the delivery scheduleAodhan Connolly, spokesman for the Northern Irish wing of the British Retail Consortium, said that given the pressures on the system, deliveries should be left for only the elderly, infirm and at-risk.He also indicated that supermarkets are on something of a hiring spree right now, because of the extra manpower needed to pick customers’ baskets of groceries and deliver them.He was speaking just as the News Letter carried out a snap survey of how dferent supermarkets are catering to this spike in demand.This reporter, based in east Antrim, attempted to order groceries from five big chains which are known to deliver .Iceland did not allow this reporter to look at available delivery slots online for  minutes, because there was a queue for doing so.When it did display the delivery times, there was just one slot availablebetween noon today and Sunday, May .Sainsbury’s showed no availability for at least an entire week, ending Monday, May .Asda was unavailable until Sunday May  when some evening slots were free – but only for orders which had no alcohol.Tesco had no slots available until at least Sunday, March  .SuperValu’s nearest storecould not be reached by phone, but it is understood said they deliver only to the elderly and vulnerable, and then only in “the local community”.Mr Connollytold the News Letter: “We’ve had a growth in deliveries that’s unprecedented. We’ve seen some retailers doing delivery numbers they thought they’d be doing in eight years’ time.“But there’s a big, big thing here - there are people out there, disabled, elderly, and we’re asking the public to think before they click. Quite simply, delivery slots should be for the most vulnerable in society.”Instead the public should either get their own groceriesor get click-and-collects.The whole surge means that “here in Northern Ireland our retailers are hiring proportionately... some are permanent contracts, some are temporary”.He said they were “hiring for attitude, and training for skill” - meaning people with few qualications can still find roles in the supermarkets.He also said that “one of the laziest  narratives out there is that retailers are making a killing”. Rather, their margins have been squeezed by people buying cheaper ‘own brand’ goods instead of treating themselves.Lastly, he voiced “pride” in how day-to-day staff are handling themselves in the crisis, adding there is a “zero tolerance” approach to people shouting and becoming confrontationalasked to socially distance themselves.A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: terex to re open omagh factory
story: Terex will resume production at a reduced capacity at all their sites in Northern Ireland, including in Omagh, from Monday, May .The decision was taken in compliance with local mandates and in response to customer demand and need, the company said.Where team members can work from home we are continuing to facilitate this, a spokesperson comment.This decision follows the Department for the Economy’s recent publication permitting a list of priority business sectors, which includes Terex, to continue to operate during the COVID- in the UK.Our primary focus during the COVID- pandemic is to ensure that we look after the health, safety and well-being of our workforce, and to do all that we reasonably can to protect our team members while at work.Our employees’ health and well-being is at the centre of our operations, and in order to keep our ing employees and workplace safe from the virus we have implemented comprehensive safety measures in line with Government guidance and Terex best practice.In particular we have conducted risk assessments and are following the guidance as set out in the Northern Ireland Practical Guide to making workplaces Safer’.Going forward, in addition to our other COVID- safety and preventive measures, we are introducing three compulsory enhanced measures to help protect the health and safety of team members and others who may need to come to our sites:. Health Checks Upon Entrance: COVID- health check self-assessment utilising the Health and Social Care Application and no-touch temperature screening checks to screen for high temperatures and avoid having sick persons on our site. Face coverings will be mandatory for close working and or face to face conversations. Social distancing measures across the sitesThese measures also extend to visitors to sites, and visitors will be on an essential basis only.By taking a series of actions we can reduce risk and improve our confidence that we can operate in a safe work environment. We anticipate that these measures will be in place for the foreseeable future.Our Leadership team will continue to monitor the situation daily.
